Graphical abstract The characteristics, challenges and recent modifying strategies of four representative anode materials for rechargeable lithium batteries are discussed and summarized in detail, including graphite, Li4Ti5O12, silicon, and lithium metal. Rechargeable lithium batteries have been widely regarded as a revolutionary technology to store renewable energy sources and extensively researched in the recent several decades. As an indispensable part of lithium batteries, the evolution of anode materials has significantly promoted the development of lithium batteries. However, since conventional lithium batteries with graphite anodes cannot meet the ever-increasing demands in different application scenarios (such as electric vehicles and large-scale power supplies) which require high energy/power density and long cycle life, various improvement strategies and alternative anode materials have been exploited for better electrochemical performance. In this review, we detailedly introduced the characteristics and challenges of four representative anode materials for rechargeable lithium batteries, including graphite, Li4Ti5O12, silicon, and lithium metal. And some of the latest advances are summarized, which mainly contain the modification strategies of anode materials and partially involve the optimization of electrode/electrolyte interface. Finally, we make the conclusive comments and perspectives, and draw a development timeline on the four anode materials. This review aims to offer a good primer for newcomers in the lithium battery field and benefit the structure and material design of anodes for advanced rechargeable lithium batteries in the future. Keywords Lithium batteries Anode Graphite Li4Ti5O12 Silicon Silicon composite anode Lithium metal 1 Introduction At present, a majority of our daily energy sources come from non-renewable fossil fuels and nuclear energy. However, serious air pollution arising from fossil fuels and potential hazards brought by radioactive nuclear waste have driven people to seek new, green and renewable energy sources [1]. Fortunately, various sustainable energy sources are already in full swing, such as wind power, hydroelectric power, photovoltaic cells, fuel cells and photoelectrochemical cells [2]. Simultaneously, the generated electrical energy requires an energy storage device for balanced supply and convenient use. Rechargeable lithium batteries have been widely regarded as a powerful energy storage technology, which can provide abundant electrical energy and be recharged to reuse for many cycles [3]. Recently, a lithium-metal cell with high energy density exceeding 500 Wh kg−1 based on anionic redox activity of Li2O-based cathode has been reported [4]. After more than 100 stable cycles, the energy density can still maintain 400 Wh kg−1. What’s more, such lithium battery system is suitable for large-scale production due to the low cost. Rechargeable lithium batteries have been universally applied in personal life, social production and national armed forces (for instance, portable electronic devices, electric vehicles, large-scale energy storage system, handheld devices, missiles, satellites) due to the advantages of low self-discharge, long lifespan, high output voltage and high energy density, which have significantly changed our lives and era [5]. And the demand and quality of rechargeable lithium batteries will continue to grow with the booming development of flexible electronic devices and electric vehicles. The first rechargeable lithium metal battery (lithium secondary battery) using titanium disulfide (TiS2) as cathode and lithium metal as anode was fabricated by Stanley Whittingham in 1974 [6]. Also in the 1970s, the concept of rocking-chair battery was proposed, which explained that lithium ions could be reversibly intercalated into both anodes and cathodes and shuttle back and forth between the positive and negative electrodes [7]. Then the rocking-chair battery (also named lithium-ion battery) was extensively researched especially after LiCoO2 cathode was proposed by Goodenough in 1979 [8], and attained primary success in the Japanese battery companies in the 1980s [9]. Simultaneously, in the later 1980s, the lithium metal batteries (LMBs) with MoS2 cathode and excess lithium metal anode were commercialized by Moli Energy, but frequent short circuits and fires occurred in practical applications due to the formation of dendritic lithium metal. Subsequently, some other battery companies also conducted a mass of researches and tests on lithium metal batteries, but still suffered from the unsolvable safety issues [10]. In 1991, Sony initially commercialized lithium-ion batteries using LiCoO2 as cathode and petroleum coke as anode [11]. For the reason of the presence of Li in an ionic state rather than metallic state, lithium-ion batteries have greater safety and cycle stability, and have been used on his day ever since. In contrast, the researches on lithium metal batteries began to be abandoned and the development was sluggish due to the prosperous development of lithium ion batteries (LIBs). Nowadays, the energy density of lithium-ion batteries is close to limitation, and the newly emerging rechargeable lithium-sulfur battery and lithium-air battery systems possessing ultrahigh theoretical energy density motivate people to enthusiastically research the lithium metal batteries again with continuously evolving characterization technology and material science. And the pathway to the revival of lithium metal anodes has just begun.. In general, rechargeable lithium batteries can be divided into LIBs and LMBs. Take the conventional commercial LIBs with LiCoO2 cathode and carbonaceous anode as an example. A lithium-ion cell contains an anode, a cathode, a separator, electrolyte and a casing. The electrochemistry reactions inside LIBs can be described as follows: (1) Cathode : LiCoO 2 ↔ Li 1 - x CoO 2 + x Li + + x e - , (2) Anode : 6 C + x Li + + x e - ↔ Li x C 6 . During the battery charging process, lithium ions are detched from the cathode into the electrolyte and electrons are released from the cathode by the applied external field through the external circuit. Then the lithium ions react with electrons to insert into the carbonaceous anode. Such charging process can convert electrical energy into chemical energy via the electrochemical redox reaction. And the reaction of discharging process is opposite to that of the charging process [12]. As an important part of LIBs, the reaction mechanism of anode materials can be classified into three types: insertion reaction, alloying reaction and conversion reaction (Fig. 1 ) [13]. Insertion-type anodes (such as carbon, lithium titanate, TiO2) can allow lithium ions to be inserted into the material matrix with a small and reversible structural change, but usually exhibit a relatively lower theoretical capacity due to the limited amount of lithium insertion. Conversion-type anode refers to the transition metal compound M a X b (M = transition metal, X = P, S, O, F, etc.) such as Fe2O3, CuO, MoS2. In the conversion reaction, the transition metal is totally reduced to metal nanoparticles which contributes to a high capacity due to the multiple electron reactions, but the conversion-type anodes exhibit larger volume variation, higher redox potential and poor cyclic stability relative to insertion-type anodes [14]. For example, the electrochemical reaction of Fe2O3 is described as follows [15]: (3) Fe 2 O 3 + 6Li + + 6e - ↔ Fe + 3Li 2 O. Alloy-type anodes refer to semi-metal or metallic elements (or compounds) such as Si, Sn and Ge. The alloying process can deliver an ultrahigh theoretical capacity, but it is also accompanied by dramatic volume expansion and internal stress. For example, the electrochemical reaction of Sn is described as follows [16]: (4) Sn + 4.4Li + + 4.4e - ↔ Li 4.4 Sn. For LMBs, lithium metal is a conversion-pattern hostless anode [17]. Lithium ions are directly reduced to lithium metal to deposit on the lithium metal substrate in the charging process and the lithium will be stripped to be converted into lithium ions in the discharging process. In short, the key factors to outstanding anode materials for rechargeable lithium batteries can be presented as follows: low redox potential for high output voltage, excellent reversibility of Li+ intercalation/deintercalation (or plating/stripping for lithium metal anodes), structural stability during cycling, high ionic/electronic conductivity, low cost and environmental friendliness. Due to the great safety, rapid electrochemical kinetics and stable structure, the mainstream commercial anodes are still insertion-type anode materials while other types of anode materials can bring about abundant academic value and some anode materials show great prospects to replace the traditional carbonaceous anode for the new-generation rechargeable lithium battery [18]. During the past three decades, numerous research efforts have been made to improve the conventional anode materials and develop new anode materials for a better rechargeable lithium battery. In this review, we introduce the status and challenges facing four representative anode materials for rechargeable lithium batteries. These four anode materials are respectively graphite which represents the mature commercial anode materials, Li4Ti5O12 which represents the anode materials with prolonged stable cycles, silicon which represents the anode materials with high specific capacity for LIBs, and lithium metal which represents the most potential high-energy anode materials for rechargeable lithium batteries. To compare these four anodes more intuitively, we list a table (Table 1 ) on electrochemical performance and other parameters of the anode materials. Besides, this review mainly focuses on various design strategies of anode materials to improve the electrochemical performance, and partially discusses some issues of electrode/electrolyte interface which could greatly affect the utilization of anode materials. We believe that this systematic review will be a good primer for newcomers in the lithium batteries field and provide a general and fundamental understanding of anode materials for rechargeable lithium batteries. 2 Anode materials for rechargeable lithium batteries 2.1 Graphite anode Since the naissance of the first generation of commercial LIBs, carbon materials have unshakably occupied the vast majority of the anode material market [9]. Carbon materials have the advantages of high electronic/ionic conductivity, various categories, low cost, abundant raw materials, easy structure engineering, and acceptable thermal and mechanical properties [19,20]. Carbonaceous anode materials for LIBs generally include graphite, soft carbon, hard carbon, mesocarbon microbeads (MCMB) for commercial application, and carbon nanotubes, carbon nanofibers, graphene toward academia. For example, Sony company employs coke or hard carbon as anode materials exhibiting prominent cycle stability while A&T and Matsushita companies commonly adopt graphite anodes for a high energy density [21]. Wang et al. [22] prepared N-doped carbon nanofibers film through electrospinning and high-temperature carbonization. The flexible carbon nanofibers anode presented a high capacity of 702 mAh g−1 after 500 cycles at high current density of 5 A g−1, which arised from the more defect position created by N dopant in graphite domain that contributes to the elevated lithium storage ability and conductivity. Hassoun et al. [23] synthesized graphene nanoflakes via liquid phase exfoliation of graphite and casted graphene nanoflake ink onto the Cu current collector to obtain the anode. The graphene anode delivered a high reversible capacity of 1500 mAh g−1 at 100 mA g−1 due to on-demand controlled morphology with large Li+ uptake and could achieve a full-cell energy density of 190 Wh kg−1 when matching LiFePO4 cathode. During the evolution of anode materials for over thirty years, graphite gradually replaced soft carbon and hard carbon due to the lower lithiation potential, high theoretical capacity and less reversible capacity loss during first lithiation which render elevated full-cell energy density [24]. And compared with carbon nanomaterials and graphene, graphite has the superiorities of much lower irreversible capacity arising from the low surface area, small hysteresis of the voltage, high packing density and low cost, which are vital for the practical application [25,26]. Nowadays, graphite still dominates in commercial LIBs anode materials, not only due to the cost-efficient manufacturing process and small volume expansion (approximately 11%), but also because the lowest average de-/lithiation potential of ~0.2 V vs. Li/Li+ (except lithium metal anode), good cycle stability, small voltage hysteresis and high tap density are all extremely precious in terms of the practical full-cell energy density [27]. Graphite is a layered crystal, which consists of graphene layers stacked together under the effect of van der Waals forces and π-π interactions of the delocalized electron orbitals. Each graphene layer is composed of carbon atoms combined by sp 2 hybridization in a hexagonal arrangement which extends in two-dimensional direction. Therefore, the anisotropic layered structure of graphite can be divided into two kinds of surfaces: basal plane (parallel to the graphene layer) and edge plane (perpendicular to the graphene layer), and the electronic and thermal conductivity along the direction parallel to the basal plane is much higher than that of the direction perpendicular to the base plane [28]. When the battery starts charging, lithium ions can easily pass through the edge planes to intercalate between the graphene interlayers due to the weak van der Waals forces allowing the expansion of the interlayer distance for generating the graphite intercalation compounds LiC6 with the largest possible lithium content at ambient conditions, which contributes to a theoretical capacity of 372 mAh g−1 [29]. However, the Li+ diffusion coefficient of ~10−11 cm2 s−1 in the through-plane direction is much lower than that of ~10−7 to 10−6 cm2 s−1 in the edge-plane direction, which gives rise to the occurrence of Li+ insertion almost from the edge plane [30,31]. Graphite materials typically include natural graphite (NG) from upgrading the natural graphite ore and synthetic graphite (SG) from the calcination of petroleum coke or coal tar pitch at 2500 °C [32]. The high-temperature treatment endows the SG with higher purity up to 99.9% and, though, higher cost [33]. Meanwhile, the smaller crystalline domain size with isotropic orientation and more domain interfaces in SG provide better electrode kinetics, but give rise to higher irreversible capacity and lower capacity than NG [34]. Natural graphite and synthetic graphite are both widely used as the anode materials for commercial LIBs, but exhibit different proportions according to different applications and countries. Although graphite anodes own some superiorities mentioned above, they also have some inherent defects that need to be optimized and there is still plenty of room for improvement on their electrochemical performance. Generally speaking, numerous mechanisms and modification strategies have been explored to focus on two topics: graphite/electrolyte interface and rate capability. 2.1.1 Graphite/electrolyte interface During the initial charging process, the organic solvents and salt anions in the electrolyte will be partially deposited via reduction at certain low potential to form a Li+-conducting and electron-insulating passivation film named solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) on the surface of the graphite anode due to the thermodynamical instability of electrolyte component at extreme potentials [18,35,36]. And the SEI is the determinant factor for the cycle life of graphite anodes, because the SEI can prevent the solvent co-intercalation and the continuous decomposition of electrolyte during cycling [37,38]. However, employing some kinds of solvents alone cannot stabilize the graphite/electrolyte interface, such as the famous historical mystery “EC-PC disparity”, which explains that using PC solvent causes severe Li+-solvent co-intercalation and thus renders catastrophic graphite exfoliation and poor cycle life while EC solvent could produce a stable SEI to ensure the reversible Li+ de-/intercalation [39]. Recently, Xing et al. [40] proposed the explanation that EC exhibited less competitiveness of solvation against F-containing salt anions which would render partial desolvation behavior of Li+-solvent complex during the initial co-intercalation of solvated Li+ and subsequently decompose more favorable LiF to passivate graphite surface while PC exhibited stronger solvation energy than EC which caused more solvent staying in the primary solvation sheath and the occurrence of subsequent severe co-intercalation and more unfavorable organic decomposition layer on the graphite surface. This work offers guiding principles to predict whether a new electrolyte system is feasible for a stable graphite/electrolyte interface. However, EC solvent is not set once and for all, because it demonstrates poor low-temperature performance due to the high melting point and high viscosity, limited fast-charging capability arising from the high desolvation energy barrier, and incompatibility with high-voltage cathodes, which cannot satisfy current rapid development of LIBs [18,41,42]. Therefore, researchers have proposed many strategies to obtain a favorable SEI and prevent the solvent co-intercalation for a stable graphite/electrolyte interface and high-performance LIBs, even when only using PC solvent or similar solvents that compromise the interfacial stability. To stabilize the graphite/electrolyte interface can not only effectively prevent the degradation of graphite, but also sustain the excellent cycle stability and safety of graphite anode during long cycles. From another perspective, the formation of SEI will simultaneously render irreversible consumption of active Li+ and reversible capacity loss, resulting in low initial coulomb efficiency (ICE) and decreased full-cell energy density, which is also an improvable direction for graphite anodes. There are two different pathways to solve the aforementioned issues: electrolyte design and surface modification. Wang et al. [43] designed a superconcentrated electrolyte (SCE) system with 5.3 M LiFSA as lithium salt and TMP as solvent for carbonaceous anode while traditional electrolytes only have the salt concentration of 1.0 M. In such superconcentrated electrolyte, massive anions and scarce solvents will appear in the primary Li+ solvation sheath, leading to anion-derived interfacial chemistry and abundant inorganic species as the main SEI components, which is conducive to passivating anode interface and avoid solvent co-intercalation [44,45]. When applied to graphite|Li half cell, the electrolyte could attain a stable charge-discharge operation with negligible capacity attenuation for 1000 cycles at C/5. And TMP solvent also showed excellent non-flammability at high temperature, which is safer than conventional carbonate electrolytes. However, the superconcentrated electrolyte also brings a relatively high price and viscosity, which is unpractical for mass production and battery assembly processes. Zhang et al. [46] employed localized high-concentration electrolytes (LHCE) for LIBs with advanced high-voltage NMC811 anode and commercial graphite anode. The localized high-concentration electrolytes contain 1.4 M LiFSI as lithium salt, carbonate solvents as the solvating solvent and tetrafluropropyl ether (TTE) as the non-polar solvent. Since TTE barely appears in the Li+ solvation sheath, it is equivalent to diluting the concentration of the solvent and increasing the concentration of the lithium salt, which also leads to anion-derived interfacial chemistry. And this method will not increase the overall concentration and viscosity of the electrolyte, so localized high-concentration electrolytes is also named as diluted superconcentrated electrolytes. As a result, an ultrathin, uniform and compact passivation layer with abundant inorganic constituents was formed on the graphite anode surface and the full-cell performance under the high cut-off voltage of 4.4 V exhibited a long-term cycling stability in wide-temperature range (from −40 to 60 °C) at high rate. Hu et al. [47] added 5 vol% vinyl ethylene carbonate (VEC) electrolyte additive into the PC-based electrolyte for the improved anode performance. VEC can be preferentially reduced at the relatively high potential to deposit a stable and compact passivating film on the graphite anode, which effectively inhibits the co-intercalation of PC and delivered a high ICE of 85%. Apart from the electrolyte engineering, the surface modification of graphite material is also considered as the promising strategy to stabilize the graphite/electrolyte interface. Wu et al. [48] modified natural graphite with solutions of different strong oxidants ((NH4)2S2O8, concentrated nitric acid, hydrogen peroxide and ceric sulfate) through the mild and uniform liquid/solid phase oxidation to remove the reactive structural imperfections and form a fresh oxide layer on the graphite surface. The dense oxide layer without structural imperfections can reduce the electrolyte deposition and suppress the co-intercalation of solvated Li+. And the micropores and nanochannels created by the oxidation treatment could act as the extra lithium storage sites. Meanwhile, the slippage of graphene layers along the a-axis can be hindered, leading to a robust graphite structure. The graphite modified with (NH4)2S2O8 delivered an increased reversible capacity of more than 350 mAh g−1 and ICE up to 85% while pristine natural graphite only shows reversible capacity of 251 mAh g−1 and ICE of 64%. Komaba et al. [49] prepared the graphite electrodes with PAA or analogous polymer binders containing oxygen species as functional groups, and applied it in the PC-based electrolyte. The uniform polymer coating on the graphite surface can facilitate the desolvation process of solvated Li+ due to the electrostatic interaction between the positively charged Li+ and negatively charged oxygen atom in the polymer, which will permit the selective penetration of Li+ and prevent the co-intercalation of PC molecules, resulting in a significantly improved coulombic efficiency than conventional PVdF binder (Fig. 2 a and b). Yoshio et al. [50] coated a carbon coating on the spherical graphite through thermal vapor decomposition (TVD). The graphite sample with only 3 wt% carbon exhibited the initial discharge capacity of over 360 mAh g−1 with high ICE of more than 92% in both PC-based and EC-based electrolyte, which is superior to the carbon coated MCMB and uncoated spherical graphite. The tiny carbon content can deliver comparable electrochemical performance without sacrificing energy density due to the lower density of carbonaceous coating than graphite, and the carbon coating also will not increase the surface area, indicating that modifying graphite with different carbon precursors could be effective strategies to improve the long-term cycling stability for graphite anodes. Dealing with the issues of the electrode/electrolyte interface is a sustaining theme for LIBs, because the emergence of new material modification methods and new electrolytes will inevitably be accompanied by questions of whether this new interface can ensure the reversible Li+ insertion and minimize the consumption of active Li+ during long cycles. Among the aforementioned methods to stabilize the graphite/electrolyte interface, the SCE and LHCE are the most promising strategies due to the distinctive solvation structure and anion-derived interfacial chemistry, and their other advantages (such as compatibility with high-voltage cathodes, good electrochemical performances in a wide temperature range, and suppressed corrosion of current collectors) should also receive extensive attention and more researches. However, the commercialization of the technologies can only be implemented after further reducing the cost of lithium salts and seeking out inexpensive diluents. 2.1.2 Rate capability In the modern society with ever-increasing energy requirements, both portable electronic products and electric vehicles have raised high demands on the fast-charging capability of LIBs, especially in the booming electric vehicle industry. Current electric cars usually take much longer time to complete a full charge than refuelling internal-combustion-engine cars, which is one of the primary reasons that unsatisfy the consumers [51–53]. And graphite anode is considered to be the greatest obstacle for the fast-charging of commercial LIBs, because when the charging rate of graphite anode exceeds 1C, rapid capacity decay will be caused, indicating the poor rate capability [54]. More importantly, the lithiation potential of graphite (~0.1 V vs. Li/Li+) is extremely close to the potential of Li metal plating (0 V vs. Li/Li+), and various overpotential will inevitably be rendered during the high-rate charging process, causing the anode potential to drop below the dangerous 0 V and subsequently resulting in the deposition and growth of lithium metal accompanying with serious capacity attenuation and safety hazards [55]. In addition, the low charge-transfer kinetics at the electrode/electrolyte interface and limited active intercalation sites of graphite also contribute to the accumulation of lithium ions on the graphite surface at high current, which will also trigger the Li metal plating [56]. During the charging process of the graphite anode, the transmission of lithium ions inside the battery can be generally divided into four stages: (1) liquid diffusion of solvated Li+ in the bulk electrolyte, (2) the desolvation process of solvated Li+ on the SEI surface, (3) bare Li+ across the SEI, (4) solid diffusion of Li+ inside the graphite galleries [51]. If we can considerably accelerate the diffusion of lithium ions in the electrolyte (stage 1), enhance charge-transfer kinetics at the graphite/electrolyte interface (stage 2 and 3) and facilitate the rapid insertion of lithium ions into the graphite (stage 4), then anode polarization and overpotential will be greatly reduced to avoid Li plating and the fast-charging of graphite anode can become a reality. Next we will discuss the aforementioned four stages and introduce the promising strategies to improve the rate performance of graphite anodes. From the energy point of view, the energy barrier of Li+ diffusion in liquid electrolytes is inappreciable in constrast to other three stages [51]. Therefore, the collocation of the electrolyte system mainly focuses on the influence of the rate performance and cycle stability in the latter three stages. However, in case of being beneficial to the latter three stages and no compromise on the electrochemical performance, a lithium salt with high ionic conductivity can be selected, which will also improve the rate performance of the graphite anode. For example, LiFSI shows the highest ionic conductivity among various lithium salts, which is a promising candidate to replace the traditional LiPF6 [57]. In addition, only adding a small amount of LiFSI or using it as the lithium salt of a superconcentrated electrolyte presents good fast-charging capability [44,58]. The desolvation process of solvated Li+ is recognized as possessing the largest energy barrier of 50–70 kJ mol−1, which is the primary obstacle to the fast-charging of graphite anodes, especially at sub-zero temperatures [59]. In commercial LIBs, such high activation energy of desolvation is mainly attributed to the EC solvent although it ensures the stable operation of the battery. Hence, using weakly solvating solvents, altering the structure of Li+ solvation sheath, or catalysing the desolvation process by active sites on the graphite plane to reduce the kinetic energy barrier are essential for fast-charging [51]. Recently, more articles about accelerating desolvation kinetics have focused on introducing different solvents or adding electrolyte additives to change the structure of the Li+ solvent sheath for lithium metal batteries. However, articles on this content for LIBs with graphite anodes are rare. Besides, Okoshi et al. [60] theoretically investigated the desolvation energies of different solvent species interacting with Li+, which offered a general guide to choose a solvent with a fast desolvation capabilbity. SEI film contains an inner inorganic layer and an outer organic layer. The inorganic layer is chemically stable and can effectively passivate the graphite, while the outer inorganic layer will still be reduced and promote the continuous electrolyte decomposition during cycling, especially in the case of fast charging, which will render the thickening SEI and increase battery impedance [61–63]. In addition, the induced internal stress by the volume expansion of graphite during prolonged cycles can also cause the rupture of the SEI, the continuous electrolyte decomposition and the subsequent SEI growth [64]. Therefore, a thin, compact, inorganic-dominated SEI film with high ionic conductivity is desirable for fast-charging of graphite anodes. Except that the superconcentrated electrolytes, localized high-concentration electrolytes and electrolyte additives mentioned in Section 2.1.1 can be the effective strategies to produce protective film with abundant inorganic components and facilicate Li+ diffusion, constructing a functional artificial SEI layer with high ionic conductivity on the graphite surface could also contribute to the excellent rate capability. Kim et al. [65] modified graphite with an amorphous Al2O3 coating through the simple sol–gel method (Fig. 2c). The Al2O3 layer can improve the wettability of the electrode material to promote the electrolyte penetration inside the graphite anode, which demonstrated the enhanced electrochemical kinetics for Li+ insertion and cycle stability in both half cell and full cell assembled with boron-doped lithium cobalt oxide. The graphite anode with 1 wt% Al2O3 delivered a reversible capacity of 337.1 mAh g−1 at a high current density of 4 A g−1 with a capacity retention of 97.2% in contrast to that of 0.1 A g−1. Natural graphite is commonly flake-like and the high anisotropy determines that the dimension of its basal plane is much larger than that of the edge plane, which increases the diffusion pathway of lithium ions to reach the edge plane due to massive basal plane parallel to the direction of current collector and obstructs the rapid Li+ insertion. The simplest way to solve this problem is spheroidization. The uniformly distributed spherical graphite can not only increase the packing density of the electrode, but also greatly reduce the probability of parallel-to-the-current-collector orientation of the basal plane [50]. Similarly, Billaud et al. [66] employed a simple magnetic alignment technology to align all graphite flakes perpendicularly to the current collector during fabrication. This ingenious architecture can expose massive edge planes and greatly shorten the diffusion pathway of Li+, exhibiting more than 2 times the lithium storage capacity than the conventional reference electrode at high rates. Besides, Cheng et al. [67] directly produced micron-sized holes in the graphite surface by KOH etching agent and heat treatment at 800 °C. The obtained multi-channel structure provides more active sites for Li+ insertion both from the edge plane and basal plane and decreases the Li+ diffusion distance inside the graphite (Fig. 2d), thus resulting in excellent rate capability. When applied in a full cell, the KOH etched Graphite respectively showed a higher capacity retention rate of 93% and 74% after 100 cycles at 3 and 6 C than that of about 85% and 48% for the original graphite anode. Xu et al. [68] prepared the expanded graphite (EG) from natural graphite flake and then mixed EG with CNT to obtain the porous graphite nanosheets (PGN)/CNT composite electrode, in which CNT was distributed between graphene sheets and could effectively avoid the restack of graphite sheets (Fig. 2e). The enlarged interlayer distance between graphene sheets and numerous through-holes in the graphite nanosheets can provide more Li+ transport space and promote the rapid intercalation of Li+. And the high desolvation energy was considered as the main reason for hindering the fast-discharging of PGN/CNT anode, so a new solvent DIOX with low desolvation energy was introduced into the electrolyte. DIOX showed much decreased charge transfer resistance at room temperature and excellent low-temperature performance at −40 °C while conventional EC solvent presented no capacity at −40 °C. As a consequence, the PGN/CNT anode could deliver a high reversible capacity of 220 mAh g−1 at 8 C and reach a capacity retention of 90% after 500 cycles at 4 C. From the above discussion, we can see that the kinetics of the interface reaction is more important for the rate performance of the graphite anodes compared with the modification of graphite materials. So more researches should focus on the improvement of the electrolyte based on the accurate desolvation mechanism to reduce the activation energy of desolvation process for graphite anodes, and the kinetics of Li+ passing through the SEI should be valued for a favorable natural SEI and well-designed artificial SEI. Surface coatings can function as the artificial SEI to stabilize the graphite/electrolyte interface and enhance the rate capability, but the requirements for the selection of coating materials and coating technique are rigorous. Greater efforts could be made on how to apply the surface coatings to the large-scale industrial production line and solving the possible issues of incompatibility with electrode slurry and electrolyte components. 2.2 Li4Ti5O12 anode Among commercial non-carbon anode materials, spinel Li4Ti5O12 occupies a considerable proportion and exhibits promising prospects for powering the energy storage systems of electric vehicles due to the high safety, environmentally friendliness, relatively low manufacturing cost and excellent electrochemical performance [69,70]. Spinel Li4Ti5O12 can allow the insertion of three lithium ions per unit cell to form rock-salt Li7Ti5O12, which contributes to the theoretical capacity of 175 mAh g−1. In the face-centered cubic structure of spinel Li4Ti5O12, the insertion of lithium ions changes the position of most lithium ions in the original unit cell to make the lithium ions fully occupy the empty octahedral 16c sites in which half of the lithium ions come from external insertion and the other half derives from the transfer of lithium ions from the original tetrahedral 8a sites [71]. This two-phase reaction process is accompanied by a slight change in lattice parameter from 8.3595 to 8.3538 Å, combining with the strong covalent bonding between Ti and O atoms in structures, which make Li4Ti5O12 recognized as “zero strain” electrode material with negligible volume changes and extremely stable structure during the charging/discharging process [72,73]. What’s more, Li4Ti5O12 possesses a considerably flat and high charge–discharge voltage plateau of about 1.55 V (vs. Li/Li+), which can avoid the formation of SEI film arising from electrolyte reduction at below 1 V [74]. Compared with graphite anodes, the absence of SEI can greatly reduce the consumption of active Li+ in the first cycle, increase the coulombic efficiency during cycling, improve the compatibility with various electrolyte systems, and facilitate Li+ diffusion across the interfaces. Besides, the high potential could significantly inhibit the formation of lithium dendrites, thus ensuring the safety of the battery [75]. All the aforementioned merits give rise to the excellent cycling stability, making Li4Ti5O12 become one of the most attractive and extensively researched anode material candidates for large-scale energy storage applications [76]. However, due to the lack of electrons in 3d orbital of Ti, Li4Ti5O12 is subjected to poor electrical conductivity (10−8–10−13 S cm−1) and low lithium diffusion coefficient (10−9–10−16 cm−2 s−1), which severely limits its rate capability and hinders the practical applications for charging/discharging at high rates [77–79]. To tackle the issues, many improvement methods have been proposed to enhance the conductivity of Li4Ti5O12 anodes, which could be summarized into two categories: the design of micro/nanostructure and structural modification. 2.2.1 Design of nano/microstructure It is well known that nanometerization of anode materials is able to bring bout unexpected physical and electrochemical properties due to a size confining effect. Nanoscale Li4Ti5O12 can greatly shorten the Li+/electron transport distance and provide a large specific surface area to fully contact with the electrolyte [80], resulting in rapid Li+/electron diffusion rates and significantly enhanced rate capability [81]. Besides, the nanostructured Li4Ti5O12 can decrease the volume strain during lithiation/delithiation and thus render the improved cycle stability. Li4Ti5O12 nanomaterials include various morphologies, such as 0D nanoparticles, 1D nanowires, nanotubes, nanorods, 2D nanosheets, thin film. Except for merely preparing Li4Ti5O12 nanomaterials through different methods, we can also use these nano-sized building blocks to assemble sophisticated nano/microstructure, which could further improve the mechanical and electrochemical properties [82,83]. Simultaneously, nano-Li4Ti5O12 will also bring some shortcomings of difficult control on dimensions of materials, low volumetric energy density, more unwanted side reactions at electrode/electrolyte interface, and strong aggregation between nanoparticles [84], which should be significantly noticed and optimized during the electrode design. Liu et al. [85] prepared mesoporous Li4Ti5O12 nanoparticles through a facile hydrothermal method in ethanol/water solution and subsequent heat treatment at 700 °C. The Li4Ti5O12 nanoparticles showed an uniform mesoporous morphology with an average pore size of 5 nm, which further increased the surface area of nanoparticles and provided more active insertion sites with low activation energy. As a result, a high discharge capacity of 145 mAh g−1 with a capacity retention of 96% was obtained after 200 cycles at 20 C. Shen et al. [86] directly grew Li4Ti5O12 nanowires on the Ti foil via hydrothermal and chemical lithiation, and then calcined the precursor in H2/Ar atmosphere to creat Ti3+ sites in the spinel Li4Ti5O12 to obtain the H-LTO NWAs anode (Fig. 3 a). The direct connection between the current collector and active material can not only facilitate the transmission of electrons, but also eliminate the use of conductive agents and binders to increase the overall energy density. The greatly enhanced electronic conductivity due to introducing Ti3+ and facile electrolyte diffusion arising from the large open space between nanowires all contribute to excellent rate capability, resulting in a reversible capacity of 149 mAh g−1 with a capacity retention of 95% at 5 C after 100 cycles. Wang et al. [87] employed a simple solvothermal method and thermal treatment to prepare ultrathin mesoporous Li4Ti5O12 nanosheets (UM-LTONS) with a controlled thickness of 1 nm and abundant mesopores (~10 nm) on the nanosheets. The ultrathin mesoporous structure can greatly shorten the diffusion distance of Li+/electrons and offer more electrochemical reaction sites due to the high specific surface area of 181.7 m2 g−1. After 2500 cycles, the UM-LTONS anode could still maintain the capacity of 145.3 mAh g−1 with a high capacity retention of 95% at 20 C. Wang et al. [88] successfully synthesized Li4Ti5O12 hierarchical microspheres self-assembled by interconnected nanosheets (Fig. 3b) via a strictly controlled solvothermal method in a moderate reaction temperature and the subsequent short annealing process. Compared with those Li4Ti5O12 nanomaterials, this well-designed microstructure can effectively increase the tap density up to 1.32 g cm−3 for a high volumetric energy density without sacrificing the advantages of nanoscale and show moderate surface areas of more than 51.91 m2 g−1. Furthermore, when applied to the full cell with LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 cathode, a high capacity retention of 93.4% was achieved after 1000 cycles at 3 C, indicating the excellent rate performance and great prospects for commercial applications. In general, constructing different Li4Ti5O12 nanomaterials is the vital and but basic procedure to obtain advanced Li4Ti5O12 anode with outstanding rate performance and cycle stability, and the synthesis steps and conditions need to be strictly tailored to attain the desired morphologies. More researches should be focused on the rational preparation of Li4Ti5O12 nano/microstructures using different nanostructured building blocks to overcome the intrinsic defects of nanomaterials and increase the volumetric energy density. 2.2.2 Structural modification Based on the design of nano/microstructures, we can also improve the conductivity of Li4Ti5O12 materials and obtain better electrochemical performance through modifying the structure of Li4Ti5O12, which is usually implemented by two different strategies of surface coating and ion doping. Carbon coating is the most common method to modify Li4Ti5O12 due to the excellent electronic conductivity, good chemical stability, light weight, low cost and facile preparation process, which not only improves the conductivity of Li4Ti5O12, but also constitutes a continuous conductive network to shorten the transport distance of electrons and reduce the interfacial resistance between nanoparticles [89]. Wang et al. [90] prepared monodisperse Li4Ti5O12 nanospheres coated with an ultrathin carbon layer via the hydrolysis of TiN in a stable alkaline environment and subsequent calcination at high temperature. The carbon precursor PVP was directly added into the precursor solution of LTO, which could not only simplify the preparation steps, but also prevent the agglomeration of the nanospheres and limit the particle size in the carbonization process. This nanosphere anode with carbon coating exhibits high tap density of 1.1 g cm−3 and enhanced electronic conductivity up to 1.01 × 10−6 S cm−1, leading to an excellent rate capability (108.9 mAh g−1 at 80 C) and cycle stability (capacity retention of 92.6% after 500 cycles at 10 C). Roh et al. [91] fabricated C/Li4Ti5O12/rGO microspherical composite consisting of Li4Ti5O12 nanoparticles with the size of ~20 nm anchored on rGO sheets (Fig. 3c) through one-pot spray-drying method and heat treatment. In the precursor solution, ethylene glycol solvent can not only be used as the carbon source to coat nanoparticles, but also function as a stabilizer to reduce the hydrolysis rate of Ti(OC2H5)4 for a smaller nanoparticle size. And rGO enabled significantly improving the electronic conductivity of composite materials and reducing the charge-transfer resistance of the electrode. In addition, at 60 °C, the C/Li4Ti5O12/rGO composite anode delivered a high capacity retention of 93% after 1000 cycles at 10 C while Li4Ti5O12/rGO only exhibited the capacity retention of 57% at the same condition, indicating that the carbon coating can prevent direct contact between the electrolyte and Li4Ti5O12 to reduce the occurrence of side reactions for improving the cycling stability. Despite carbon coating has been demonstrated as an efficient method to improve the rate performance of Li4Ti5O12, the choice of carbon source and thickness must be modestly considered to ensure the coating quality and the rapid Li+ insertion. And the heteroatom doped carbon [92] and in-situ formed carbon should be further researched respectively due to the enhanced interface kinetics and perspective for large-scale production. In addition to conventional carbon coatings, metal [93], metal oxide [94], polymers [95], and TiN [96] coating have also been investigated to improve the electrochemical performance and even specific capacity of Li4Ti5O12. Besides, seeking more novel conductive coating and facile preparation technology is valuable for Li4Ti5O12 anodes. Unlike the conductive coating which only ameliorates the surface conductivity of Li4Ti5O12, ion doping can improve the intrinsic electronic conductivity and Li+ diffusion rate of Li4Ti5O12 materials by generating a charge compensated mixture (Ti3+/Ti4+) and increasing the lattice parameter. Numerous anions and cations could be doped into the crystal structure of Li4Ti5O12 by replacing the positions of Li, Ti or O to form various phase structures and improve the original properties, such as K+ [97], Ca2+ [98], Cr3+ [99], Mo6+ [100], F− [101], Br− [102]. Yi et al. [103] employed the simple solid-state synthesis method with Na2CO3 as sodium source to prepare the Na+-doped spinel Li4− x Na x Ti5O12. Compared with the original Li4Ti5O12, the smaller particle size of Li3.95Na0.05Ti5O12 (400–600 nm) is conducive to more efficient electrolyte contact. And, Na+ possesses larger ionic radius (1.02 Å) than that of Li+ (0.76 Å), which can not only increase the lattice constant to accelerate Li+ diffusion, but also introduce defects due to lattice distortion for more lithium storage sites. The optimized Li3.9Na0.1Ti5O12 anode delivered a reversible capacity of 133 mAh g−1 with no capacity decay after 200 cycles at 5 C while the pristine Li4Ti5O12 only exhibited the capacity of 93 mAh g−1, indicating the excellent reversibility at high rates. Hou et al. [104] prepared Zr4+-doped Li4Ti5− x Zr x O12 nanosheets via a simple one-pot hydrothermal method using Zr(NO3)4·6H2O as dopant. Zr-doping is capable of not only improving the crystallinity of spinel Li4Ti5O12 without altering the basic structure, but also promoting the reduction of partial Ti4+ to Ti3+ (13.0% in Li4Ti4.85Zr0.15O12) due to the charge compensation effect to greatly enhance the electronic conductivity. The optimized Li4Ti4.85Zr0.15O12 anode showed a high initial discharge capacity of 206.4 mAh g−1 at 1 C even exceeding the theoretical capacity and could still maintain the capacity of 133.3 mAh g−1 after 500 cycles at 10 C. Salvatore et al. [105] employed NH4Cl to dope Cl− into the hierarchical Li4Ti5O12 nanoflower structure through the hydrothermal process. DFT calculations revealed that Cl-doping significantly reduced the band gap of Li4Ti5O12 from the original 2.01 to 0.83 eV and brought about volume expansion of 2.75% compared to the original Li4Ti5O12 to expand Li+ transfer channel in the lattice structure, leading to improved electronic/ionic conductivity and 12% higher capacity during 100 cycles at 2 C. Ion doping provides a convenient and economical method of in-situ adding a small amount of dopant to improve the electrochemical performance of Li4Ti5O12. Simultaneously, some cation/cation and cation/anion co-doping researches have also been investigated to utilize the synergistic effects to further enhance the rate performance and structural stability, which deserve more experiments and theoretical analysis to exploit additional favorable properties. Besides, more high-quality dopants and lithiation mechanisms of element-doped Li4Ti5O12 should be explored for optimizing the design principles of ion doping. 2.2.3 Gassing problem Except for the inherently low conductivity, gassing behavior that occurs during charge/discharge or even storage process renders severe battery swelling and safety issues, especially at elevated temperatures [106]. Such phenomenon cannot be easily observed in coin cells, but it is obvious in the practical soft-packed full battery [73,107]. In addition, the gassing issues will also hinder Li+ transport, reduce power density and deteriorate battery lifespan, which significantly limits the commercial and industrial applications of Li4Ti5O12 batteries [108]. Common gases include H2, CO, CO2, C2H4. Despite the gassing sources and correlative formation mechanisms have not been fully understood, this phenomenon has been demonstrated to closely concern the Li4Ti5O12 surface, electrolyte and operation conditions [109]. Due to the high operation voltage, a stable passivation layer could not be produced on the Li4Ti5O12 surface, which causes direct contact between Li4Ti5O12 and electrolyte and triggers a series of decarboxylation, dehydrogenation, decarbonylation and reduction reactions at Li4Ti5O12/electrolyte interface. Meanwhile, the ratios and species of electrolyte solvent and solute will result in huge variation about the categories and quantity of gas, and even trace amount of water can become a vital source of H2 [110]. Besides, high temperature and overcharge will also aggravate the gas generation. More detailed gas formation mechanism and influencing factors can refer to the two systematic reviews [109,111]. Therefore, some relevant solutions have been proposed to suppress gas generation. For example, functional surface coatings can be applied to prevent direct contact between electrolyte and Li4Ti5O12 and suppress cell swelling [112,113]. The introduction of electrolyte additives can form a stable and smooth SEI on the Li4Ti5O12 surface to inhibit the electrolyte deposition [114]. And the selection of appropriate solvent can greatly reduce the gas evolution [115]. In general, for the practical application of Li4Ti5O12 anodes, a multifunctional solution or several synergistic strategies should be scrupulously tailored to simultaneously tackle the challenges of poor rate capability due to low conductivity and inferior cycle stability arising from the gassing issues. 2.3 Different dimensions of silicon anode Nowadays, the specific capacities of commercially available anodes like graphite and Li4Ti5O12 almost reach their theoretical values and face great challenge for further improvement. The low theoretical capacity of these insertion anodes significantly limits the specific capacity and energy density of commercial LIBs, which cannot meet the ever-increasing demands of high power density and high energy density especially for electric vehicles and hybridelectric vehicles. Hence, pursuing alternative anodes with adequately high specific capacity (>1000 mAh g−1) and matched high capacity cathodes (250–300 mAh g−1) is an urgent and valuable task, which can provide more than twice the specific capacity of the full battery compared to the current lithium battery system [116]. Fortunately, silicon, an alloy-type anode, owns a theoretical capacity 10 times higher than that of graphite anode, which can make up for the above-mentioned defects and is considered as one of the most promising anode materials for the next-generation high-energy LIBs [117,118]. Silicon is especially abundant in the earth crust (about 26.4%), the reserves of which are second only to oxygen. And silicon is widely used in various semiconductor industries with a mature manufacturing process, resulting in relatively low cost. As an anode material, Silicon can be electrochemically lithiated via a two-phase mechanism to form the final phase Li22Si5 (theoretical capacity of 4200 mAh g−1) at high temperature (415 °C) and Li15Si4 (theoretical capacity of 3579 mAh g−1) at room temperature [119]. What’s more, silicon exhibits a relatively low delithiation potential of about 0.4 V vs. Li/Li+, which can not only render the relatively high operating voltage, but also avoid surface lithium precipitation to improve the safety [120]. However, the huge volume expansion/shrinkage (expansion rate ~300%) during lithiation/delithiation not only causes the fracture and pulverization of silion arising from irrecoverable stress (Fig. 4 a), but also weakens the electrical contact between the active material and the current collector. After many cycles, the varying volume of the total electrode results in electrode peel-off (Fig. 4b) and eventually capacity fading [121]. The SEI film is also a significant factor for silicon-based anodes. During the lithiation of silicon, the electrolyte undergoes a side reaction at a low potential (<0.5 V vs. Li/Li+) to form an SEI film and deposit on the surface of the silicon particles. With the subsequent huge expansion and contraction of the silicon volume, the fragile SEI film will rupture, then the fresh silicon will be exposed to the electrolyte again and consume the active Li+ to form a new SEI layer (dead lithium), causing the SEI layer to continue thickening (Fig. 4c), which will not only reduce the coulombic efficiency and ionic conductivity, but also make the full battery with silicon anodes rapidly fail [122]. Therefore, the formation of a stable SEI is also a hot research topic for silicon-based anodes. Furthermore, as a semiconductor material, silicon has quite low electronic conductivity (~10−3 S cm−1) and Li+ diffusion coefficient (~10−13 cm2 s−1), which greatly limits the rate capability [123]. So far, there is still a long way to transform advanced silicon anode materials from the laboratory to practical commercial and industrial applications which require high energy density, long cycle life, fast charge/discharge capability, low cost, and high safety. Anyway, first we entail overcoming the challenges of the huge volume effect and extremely low conductivity. In the past twenty years, researchers have made great efforts and proposed numerous feasible strategies. Here, we will describe silicon anode materials in different dimensions and discuss the derivative issues during the exploration process. 2.3.1 Zero-dimensional nanoparticles The nanometerization of silicon is considered to be one of the most promising ways to improve the electrochemical performance of silicon [124,125]. Reasonably designing silicon nanostructures (such as Si nanoparticles, Si nanowires, Si nanotubes, Si thin films) can effectively improve the cycle stability and rate performance of silicon anodes [117,126]. Compared with bulk silicon or micron-sized silicon particles, silicon nanoparticles have the advantages of short Li+ diffusion distance and fast electrons transport due to the large specific surface area and small sizes and could alleviate surface hoop tension upon lithiation without obvious cracking [127]. In more detail, Liu et al. proposed a cracking regulation based on the accurate size of silicon nanoparticles, which explained that when the diameter of silicon nanoparticles is larger than 150 nm, surface cracking and particle fracture would occur during the initial lithiation, otherwise the nanoparticles would avoid cracking because of insufficient strain energy [128]. This discovery has played an important guiding role in the design of silicon nanostructures and the development of related research in the future. Commercially available silicon nanoparticles are typically derived from the high-temperature pyrolysis of toxic silane through the CVD process, which represents high production costs and complicated process conditions [129]. In order to realize the commercialization of silicon-based anodes, it is inevitable to exploit simple preparation methods and cost-efficient silicon sources with abundant reserves. Tang et al. [130] used halloysite clay as the SiO2 precursor to prepare pure silicon nanoparticles through acid etching, compacting and magnesiothermic reduction process, which is applicable to large-scale production and enhances the silicon yield up to more than 70% of total Si element. The obtained silicon nanoparticles can reach a high capacity of 735.1 mAh g−1 at a high current density of 5 A g−1 for 1000 cycles. Lin et al. [131] prepared crystalline silicon nanoparticles through aluminothermic reduction of high silica zeolite in the molten AlCl3 system and the relatively high yield of 75% can be achieved at the low converting temperature of 250 °C, which could save energy and be applied to various raw materials containing SiO2 (Fig. 5 a). The Si nanoparticles anode exhibited a high specific capacity of 870 mAh g−1 at 3 A g−1 after 1000 cycles. Cui’s group [132] initially adopted low-grade ferrosilicon pieces as the raw materials and controlled high-energy mechanical ball milling method without any high-temperature process. The mechanically weak metal impurities were almost exposed on the surface of Si nanoparticles when the size was inferior to 100 nm and removed via the subsequent acid treatment to obtain the Si nanoparticles with ultrahigh purity of up to 99.999%. The carbon-coated Si nanoparticles anode delivered a capacity retention of 73% at 0.5 C after 500 cycles with the average coulombic efficiency of 99.81%. Although silicon nanoparticles can significantly improve the rate performance and cycle stability of silicon anodes, their intrinsic properties also bring about some thorny issues, such as low initial coulombic efficiency (ICE), poor thermal stability, and low areal capacity, which seriously hinder the practical application of nano-silicon anode [133]. Due to the larger specific surface area of silicon nanoparticles than micron-sized silicon or bulk silicon, more active lithium ions are consumed by the electrolyte and the natural oxide layer on the surface of silicon nanoparticles to form SEI and irreversible lithium silicates during the first lithiation process, which results in high irreversible capacity and low ICE. What’s more, the capacity loss of silicon electrodes are also derived from crystalline-to-amorphous transition, lithium accommodation in conductive agent and binder, and fractured or isolated silicon particles [134]. Compared with the commercial graphite electrode with the ICE of 90%–94%, the ICE of nano-silicon anodes only ranges from 65% to 85% [133], which significantly reduces the energy density of the full battery. Besides, more side reactions with electrolyte also render thermal instability, which easily causes safety problems [135]. To tackle the aforementioned issues, the design of micron-sized secondary structure, prelithiation and adding electrolyte additives are all effective strategies. The well-designed micron-sized silicon structure can not only reduce the SEI formation due to the reduced surface area, but also isolate the electrolyte from the outer protective layer, thus forming a stable SEI. Liu et al. [136] assembled a pomegranate-inspired secondary structure containing numerous Si/C yolk-shell nanoparticles via the microemulsion method. The secondary structure with the size of 1 μm possesses a specific SEI area of ~15 m2 g−1 relative to ~90 m2 g−1 of Si/C nanoparticles, and SEI can be steadily generated on the surface of the secondary particles due to the volumetric accommodation effect of the sufficient void space inside and outside the nanoparticles, which could effectively improve the ICE. When the active lithium inventory from the cathode is greatly consumed by silicon nanoparticles, the lithium supplement measures should be considered to compensate for the dead lithium. Prelithiation is one of the most direct strategies to improve the ICE of silicon anodes, which includes electrochemical prelithiation [137], mechanical prelithiation by compressing stabilized lithium metal powder into the silicon anode [138], adding the Li x Si nanoparticles into the anode slurry for prelithiation [139], and assembling with lithium-rich cathode to provide unrecoverable lithium reservoir [140]. Most prelithiation methods must be implemented in an inert or dry atmosphere during the whole process due to the high reactivity of lithium metal, which increases the production cost. Moreover, some prelithiation measures cannot ensure the uniformity of the lithiated particles in the active material, thus inducing the generation of lithium dendrites [141]. Cao et al. [142] deposited lithium metal coated with a PMMA protective layer on a copper current collector, and then coated silicon nanoparticles and binder on the PMMA in ambient air. The lithium/PMMA/Si nanoparticles anode can remain stable for more than 30 min in ambient air with normal humidity, which is conducive to the assembly process of standard batteries. After assembling the coin cell in carbonate-based electrolytes, PMMA is dissolved by the electrolyte and the lithium metal contacts with silicon nanoparticles to accomplish the prelithiation process under the internal pressure of the battery (Fig. 5b). Since the prelithiation process is not exposed to air and the lithium metal layer is uniformly distributed on the current collector, favourable and uniform lithiated silicon particles are obtained. As a result, the prelithiated silicon anode exhibited improved cycle stability and higher initial discharge capacity than the charge capacity which meant that the ICE is more than 100%. Adding electrolyte additives is another effective and economical strategy to improve the ICE of silicon anodes by forming a stable SEI layer and inhibiting excessive decomposition of the electrolyte. Zhu et al. [143] introduced optimal 2.5 wt% DMAA additive into the 1.0 M LiPF6/EC:DMC:DEC:FEC (3:3:3:1 weight ratio) electrolyte to improve the electrochemical performance of the silicon anodes. The silicon anode delivered an initial discharge capacity of 3665 mAh g−1 with the enhanced ICE of 80.16% and a high capacity retention of 80% after 500 cycles at 840 mA g−1. However, the effect of using electrolyte additives alone to improve ICE is still not very prominent in contrast to the above two methods. In addition, electrolyte additives have also been reported to improve the thermal stability of silicon anodes. For example, applying EC or FEC electrolyte additives into lithiated silicon nanoparticles electrodes can increase the trigger temperature of the violent exothermic reaction from 153 °C to over 200 °C due to the formation of polycarbonates [144]. During the lithiation process, the silicon particles will expand in the vertical direction and cause the electrode to thicken, while the volume shrinkage during the delithiation process may render the loss of electrical contact among the particles or between the particles and the current collector even in the case of using conductive agent and binder [145]. Therefore, normal silicon electrodes customarily have a small areal mass loading of less than 1 mg cm−2 to reserve space for the silicon expansion, which limits the energy density of the full cell to less than 250 Wh kg−1 [146]. Besides, more interparticle space between silicon nanoparticles leads to lower tap density of 0.16 g cm−3 in contrast to commercial graphite (tap density of ~1.16 g cm−3) [147]. As a result, low tap density and low mass loading together result in low areal capacity, which significantly limits the practical applications of nano-Si anodes. Therefore, more strategies for increasing tap density and areal mass loading need to be investigated to increase the areal capacity of silicon anodes while maintaining good cycling stability. As discussed above, designing a micron-sized secondary microstructure could also increase the tap density of the silicon anodes. Based on the micron-sized pomegranate-inspired structure [136], Cui’s group employed industrially mature high pressure dry press and high energy mechanical milling method to further increase the tap density up to 1.38 g cm−3, which is feasible for large-scale production due to the high yield and efficiency [148]. The controllable mechanical pressure and subsequent calcination process ensure high packing clusters with excellent electrical contact, which give rise to the stable areal capacity of 2.3 mAh cm−2 with a high mass loading of 2.2 mg cm−2 at the current density of 0.5 mA cm−2 for 100 cycles. Conductive binder is another effective tool to increase the areal capacity of silicon anodes by applying more mass loading. The advanced conductive binders can not only maintain the integrity of the electrode structure and good electrical connections among anodes, but also withstand the industrial calendering process without fracture. Hu et al. [149] synthesized a self-healing hydrogel conductive binder (ESVCA) with outstanding 3D interpenetrating conductive network and prepared nano Si-ESVCA anode by in-situ polymerization. The ESVCA binder exhibited excellent stretchability with 200%–300% strain resistance and could withstand 200% strain even after rapid self-healing owing to dynamic hydrogen bonds and electrostatic interactions while continuously maintaining good conductivity (Fig. 5c). Furthermore, enhanced adhesion and strong peeling force between nanoparticles are obtained to maintain excellent electrical contact. As a consequence, the Si-ESVCA electrodes with a high mass loading of 2.48 mg cm−2 delivered a stable areal capacity of over 5 mAh cm−2 at 0.5 mA cm−2 for 100 cycles. 2.3.2 One-dimensional nanowire/nanotube In 2007, Cui et al. [150] initially grew Si nanowires on the stainless steel substrates directly as the working anode for LIBs, which delivered a theoretical charge capacity of 4277 mAh g−1 and maintained the high discharge capacity of over 3000 mAh g−1 in the subsquent nine cycles at C/20, indicating the promising potential of the one-dimensional nanomaterials for excellent lithium storage performance. The Si nanowires directly grew on the metallic current collector ensures good electrical contact with the current collector and enables all nanowires to contribute capacity. The Si nanowires not only own the nanoscale to shorten the lithium diffusion distance, but also offer a continuous one-dimensional conductive channel to facilitate the charge transfer unlike the large interfacial resistance between silicon nanoparticles. What’s more, the mechanical strain can be reduced by the axial and radial expansion during the lithiation process and the enough empty space between nanowires accommodates the volume charge, which increases the pulverization resistance [151]. The Si nanotube is another most researched one-dimensional nanomaterials with large hollow space and thin shell. The larger surface area of Si nanotubes promotes more sufficient contact with electrolyte and increases the lithium ion flux in the interface [152]. The internal empty space not only greatly reduces the stress accumulation and the tensile stress concentration [153], but also provides additional space for the silicon expansion, which give rise to the pulverization prevention and small changes (<35%) in the axial dimension [154]. Several methods have been widely used to produce Si nanowires, such as chemical vapor deposition (CVD) [155] and supercritical-fluid-liquid–solid (SFLS) [156] based on the vapor–liquid–solid (VLS) mechanism, and the top-down metal-assisted chemical etching (MACE) [157] method. Chan et al. [158] used phenylsilane as the reactant and grew the crystalline Si nanowires with the average diameter of 24.6 nm on the Au nanocrystal seeds in the high-heat and pressurized supercritical solvent. The pristine Si nanowires produced by this SFLS method showed an initial discharge capacity of 1077 mAh g−1 with a low ICE of 34% and rapidly decreased to 151 mAh g−1 after 75 cycles, while the electrochemical performance could be greatly improved by accompanying with carbon coating or carbon nanotubes. Comparing with conventional CVD method, the Si nanowires produced via the SFLS method can be applicable to commercially large-scale slurry coating process to lower the price and the Si yield is much larger than the CVD method. Hu et al. [159] proposed a novel MCAE-based method of placing silicon substrates pre-coated with noble metal catalysts onto the graphite or noble metal substrates soaked in the aqueous HF solution fed with oxygen to produce silicon nanowires via galvanic corrosion of silicon. The facile and efficient method circumvents the use of toxic and expensive oxidizing agent and sheds light on the continuously flowing production line of Si nanowires. The MACE method can inherit the conductivity and crystal orientation of the original silicon wafer without additional doping to enhance the conductivity, but the cost of the silicon wafer is relatively high. During the prolonged cycles, the pristine silicon nanowires cannot tolerate the huge volume changes to cause the structure pulverization, which resulted in an obvious capacity fade. Moreover, the Si nanowires face the dilemmas of low capacity retention and poor structural stability at fast cycling rates, and the rate performance of this one-dimensional nanomaterial still has room for improvement. In addition, silicon nanowires usually exhibit limited mass loading and tap density, which leads to low areal capacity of <3 mAh cm−2 and thus fails to meet the commercial requirements. In such content, Chen et al. [160] employed MACE method to produce P-doped Si nanowires via etching P-doped silicon wafers (Fig. 6 a). The advantages for phosphorus doping were as follows: (1) The electrical conductivity of Si nanowires was significantly enhanced, leading to an ultrafast axial charging rates and a full crystalline Li15Si4 transformation [161]; (2) the phosphorus dopants accelerated the etching process and created numerous mesoporous holes with the diameter about 7 nm uniformly distributed on the surface of Si nanowires; (3) the nanoporous structure could effectively buffer huge volume changes and greatly increase the surface area of nanowires up to 323.47 m2 g−1 to offer more Li+/electron conductive pathway, which ensures the structural stability at high-rate currents. As a consequence, the porous Si nanowires anodes delivered a high specific capacity of 2061.1 mAh g−1 at 1.5 A g−1 after 1000 cycles and retained an extraordinary reversible capacity of 586.7 mAh g−1 at a current density of 16 A g−1 after 5000 cycles. Karuppiah et al. [162] uniformly grew Si nanowires on the graphite flakes as the composite anode in a stainless-steel pressure reactor with Au-assisted catalysis (Fig. 6b). The economic and scalable one-pot synthesis process can easily regulate the mass loading and the type of substrates without yield loss. With the optimal 32 wt% of Si, the composite electrode could maintain the excellent mechanical stability and electrical contact, and showed a limited 20% volume swelling after 100 cycles. The Si nanowires composite anodes presented a high capacity retention of 87% with a commercial tap density of 1.6 g cm−3 at 2 C after 250 cycles and a reversible capacity of 1000 mAh g−1 with a mass loading of 2.7 mg cm−2 after 100 cycles at C/5. Silicon nanotubes are typically prepared through two processes: the one is to prepare sacrificial nanofibers or nanorods template, deposit a thin silicon layer on the template through the CVD method, and finally remove the template by a high-temperature reduction process, while the other is to prepare sacrificial nanofibers or nanorods template, coat silica precursor on the template by the sol-gel method, remove the template and produce the silica nanotubes through calcination, and finally form the Si nanotubes by the magnesium thermal reduction reaction. Due to the large surface area of Si nanotubes compared to Si nanowires, more SEIs are generated on the inner and outer walls, greatly reducing the ICE. And the dimensional changes of the inner and outer walls of the Si nanotubes during the repetitive lithiation/delithiation process could cause the fracture and reconstruction of SEI, which will reduce the coulombic efficiency and hinder the Li+ transmission arising from the thickened SEI layer. Therefore, improving the stability of the interface between the silicon nanotube and the electrolyte is a significant factor. Wu et al. [163] fabricated a double-walled silicon nanotube (DWSiNTs) with an external SiO2 shell (thickness of ~10 nm) and an internal Si wall (thickness of ~20 nm) through the first process discussed above except for the final procedure of heating in air at 500 °C to remove the carbonaceous template and form a naturally oxidized SiO2 layer. The external SiO2 layer allows lithium ions to pass through to react with the active silicon inside, and the electrolyte will only contact the outer surface without penetrating into the inner wall due to the continuous tube structures. What’s more, the outer protective layer is mechanically robust enough to make the inner silicon only expand/shrink freely in the middle hollow space without mechanical fracture, so a stable and thin SEI can be formed on the static SiO2 surface (Fig. 6c and d). Benefit from this reasonable structure, the DWSiNTs anode can reach a high capacity retention of 88% at 20 A g−1 after a prolonged cycles of 6000 times and deliver a stable capacity of 900 mAh g−1 at a ultrahigh current density of 40 A g−1, indicating the extraordinary cycle stability and rate capability. 2.3.3 Two-dimensional silicon thin film Silicon thin film is a two-dimensional planar material with a thickness ranging from dozens of nanometers to a few microns, which is a promising candidate for silicon electrodes exhibiting high capacity and long cycle life [164]. Silicon thin film possesses nanoscale and high surface area to volume ratio, which is conducive to shortening Li+/electron diffusion distance and effectively mitigating the mechanical stress during the charging and discharging process [165,166]. Moreover, Si thin film can be directly deposited on the metallic substrate without extra binder, which decreases the mass of the inactive material and thus increases the energy density [117]. In the initial few cycles, the cracks will appear on the film surface due to the different directions of volumetric expansion (perpendicular to the film) and shrinkage (both perpendicular and parallel to the film), and then the gaps between the cracks will gradually magnify, utimately forming islands arising from the incremental plastic formation of Cu substrate [167]. Whereas, the surface morphology of the silicon film is almostly unchanged in the subsequent cycles. Therefore, if the internal mechanical strain of Si thin film is handled properly, the electrical contact between the islands and the current collector will still exist and the capacity loss is limited [168], which is superior to other dimensions of Si anodes. It is noteworthy that almost all the silicon thin films prepared are amorphous rather than crystalline, which exhibit higher reversible capacity and capacity retention owing to the uniform volume change and enhanced Li+ diffusion [169]. The manufacturing methods of silicon thin films could be generally divided into three categories, including physical vapor deposition (PVD), chemical vapor deposition (CVD) and electrodeposition (ED). PVD techniques can strictly control the surface morphology, thickness and deposition environment of the deposited amorphous silicon, among which magnetron sputtering technology is the most commonly used commercial technique because of its suitability for industrial scalable production and good adhesion between the produced film and the substrate. CVD method can produce high-quality amorphous or nanocrystalline silicon films according to the deposition temperature [170]. By contrast, the ED method is rarely employed, but its features of convenience, mass production and low cost have attracted wide attention from researchers recently. Gattu et al. [171] employed frequency-dependent pulse current electrodeposition technique rather than conventional DC electrodeposition to produce a continuous thin film at high frequencies with the best electrochemical performance at 5000 Hz. The obtained Si thin film delivered a capacity of 805 mAh g−1 at 300 mA g−1 after 500 cycles with a low capacity loss of 0.056% per cycle. Owing to the weak adhesion between the deposited silicon film and the metallic substrate, especially in thicker films, ordinary silicon thin film anodes exhibit a lower initial discharge capacity and a rapid capacity drop after dozens of cycles arising from the delamination of the film layer and the substrate. Roughening the substrate [172] and constructing a 3D porous current collector [173] are the corresponding solutions to increase the adhesion and electrical conduction channels, which leads to enhanced crack resistance and accommodation of volume change. Lee et al. [174] simply roughened the Cu foil to increase the surface roughness from 0.101 to 0.256 μm by sandpaper grinding and deposited a thick Si thin film of 1.5 μm via radio-frequency magnetron sputtering. The roughened surface increased contact area between the Si film and current collector with improved adhesion, which give rise to the increased initial discharge capacity from 1820 to 2300 mAh g−1 and the conspicuous decrease of capacity loss per cycle from 2.14%–0.79%, indicating the enhanced cycling stability of Si thin film by ameliorating the surface morphology of the current collector. The cracking of Si film within inactive Si phase due to the repetitive volume change accompanying with huge internal stress is still responsible for the capacity loss, which needs further efforts to improve the mechanical stability of Si thin film anode. Demirkan et al. [175] used a simple high/low pressure sputtering deposition process to prepare a density-modulated multilayer silicon thin film with alternating layers of low and high density. The low density layer with high porosity can not only accelerate the lithiation/delithiation process, but also function as a buffer layer to alleviate the stress in the high density layer and prevent the crack propagation through the low density layer (Fig. 7 a and b). After 50 cycles, the four-layer sample can still maintain a capacity of 1700 mAh g−1 with a high coulombic efficiency up to 99%. Furthermore, the intrinsic silicon film owns the defect of low electronic conductivity, which renders poor rate capability and increased pressure gradient due to the uneven lithiation [168]. The application of semiconductor silicon with additional element doping as a silicon source is considered as a comprehensive strategy to reduce the charge transfer resistance and improve the overall electrochemical performance of the silicon thin film anode. Takamura et al. [176] used crushed P-doped n-type semi-conducting Si powder as silicon source to deposit amorphous P-doped silicon thin film with a thickness of 50 nm on the roughened Ni foil via the vacuum deposited technique. Benefiting from the enhanced conductivity and modified current collector surface, the Si thin film anode delivered a high discharge capacity of more than 3000 mAh g−1 for 1000 cycles at the high current density of 12 C. In practical applications, a silicon thin film with a thickness of several microns is inevitably required to increase the capacity for matching the commercial cathode material. However, the thickness of the silicon thin film is usually inversely proportional to its electrochemical properties in a wide size range. Thinner films have reduced volume expansion and stronger adhesion with the substrate, and even could avoid cracks below the critical thickness, thus exhibiting ultrahigh reversible capacity and cycling stability [177].
