Meanwhile, it is difficult to improve the electrochemical performance of thick films, and silicon thin films can be deposited in any desired shape and thickness, so silicon thin films are extremely suitable for the emerging Li-ion microbatteries (LIMBs) which can be applied in various micro-electromechanical devices [178]. 2.3.4 Three-dimensional porous silicon Apart from utilizing the advantages of nanoscale to frabricate low-dimensional nanostructured silicon to suppress the volume effect and accelerate the Li+/electrons transmission, preparing three-dimensional hierarchical porous silicon incorporating macro-/mesoporous pores and voids in nano-silicon/micron-sized silicon/bulk silicon/hollow silicon to improve the electrochemical performance of silicon anodes has also received extensive attention and shows great prospects for practical applications [179,180]. The void space in the porous silicon not only provides sufficient space for the huge volume change of silicon to maintain the structure stability during the charge and discharge process, but also effectively reduces the internal mechanical stress generated during the lithiation process to prevent the structure pulverization, thus improving the cycle stability [181]. Besides, the interconnected porous structure also increases the surface area to facilitate the full penetration of the electrolyte and the rapid Li+ diffusion, which enhances the rate capability. The diversification of porous silicon morphology is accompanied by various production methods applied in many fields, for instance, biosensors, drug carriers, electronics [182], which also promotes its development in the energy storage fields. Electrochemical etching, CVD or gel method on templating approaches, metal-assisted chemical etching, dealloying methods, and magnesiothermic reduction are the main synthesis methods of porous silicon used for LIBs anodes. Electrochemical etching method can rapidly (<10 min) etch out numerous high aspect ratio strip hole structures on commercial silicon wafers to form a freestanding macroporous silicon film when the current is applied in the HF/electrolyte solution [183]. The macroporous silicon film could be removed from the substrate by increasing the current density to be directly used as the anode or sonicated in ethanol to convert into a particulate structure which can mix with the binders for a standard electrode slurry [184,185]. Template approaches are to use CVD to deposit silicon on the porous template or fill the voids of the porous template by silicon nanoparticles gel and then remove the SiO2 template by HF etching to form a porous silicon inverse opal structure [186,187]. Metal-assisted chemical etching uses HF/strong oxidizing agents (e.g., H2O2 or HNO3) with heavy metal (e.g., Au/Ag/Cu/Fe)-based catalyst to deposit metal on the surface of silicon particles and etch down to obtain porous silicon powders [188,189]. Although great progresses have been made on the above three methods and the obtained porous silicon exhibits good electrochemical properties, these processes inevitably involve expensive equipment and raw materials, highly toxic reactants and complex process parameters. Therefore, the development of some simple, scalable and economical production methods with cheap and sustainable silicon sources is the key factor for the practical application of porous silicon anodes. Dealloying methods refer to the utilization of relatively mild aqueous etchant (e.g., HCl/HNO3/KOH) to selectively etch the metal phase in Si-metal alloy to directly form porous silicon, which shows the advantages of simple synthesis procedures and low manufacturing costs [190]. Pathak et al. [191] milled the metallurgical grade Si-Al alloy with 50 wt% Si into fine powders with the size of ~100 μm, and then leached out entire Al phase and anisotropically etched out partial silicon by KOH to achieve a complicated porous structure. The obtained nano-porous silicon anode delivered a reversible capacity of ~1000 mAh g−1 after 300 cycles at C/3 and far exceeded commercial graphite anodes in terms of price, weight and volume on a simplified estimation about anodes for electric vehicles. However, the dealloying method has the shortcomings of long reaction time, fragile porous structure and unmanageable porosity. Magnesiothermic reduction is one of the most commonly used and most promising methods in which SiO2 is reduced by Mg vapor to Si and MgO at high temperature and then MgO is removed by HCl to obtain the porous silicon. This facile method has the following merits [192]: (1) Magnesiothermic reduction can be conducted at a lower temperature (500–950 °C) compared to traditional carbothermal reduction (2000 °C); (2) the shape of porous silicon can be easily tailored by regulating the SiO2 template; (3) various SiO2 precursors can be cheap, green and abundant on the earth. Liu et al. [193] prepared the pure SiO2 nanoparticles with the size of ~80 nm from rice husks through the facile HCl treatment at 100 °C and heating at 700 °C in air, and then conducted magnesiothermic reduction with subsquent HCl soaking to obtain the porous silicon nanoparticles (Fig. 7c). It is worth noting that rice husks are the waste by-product with the yield of 1.2 × 108 tons per year around the world and can be converted into SiO2 nanoparticles with 23 wt%, which not only far exceeds the needs of anode materials, but also can be cost-efficient and environmentally friendly. The porous silicon nanoparticles with the normal polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) binder exhibited a stable capacity of more than 1500 mAh g−1 after 300 cycles with the capacity retention of 86% at 2.1 A g−1 and obtained the coulombic efficiency of 99.3% after 100 cycles indicating the stable SEI formed on the porous silicon nanoparticles. Xiao et al. [194] synthesized a hierarchically porous silicon structure with mesoporous silicon shell and inner void core via magnesiothermic reduction of SiO2 nanospheres with mesoporous shell and solid core. The bulk SiO2 inner cores were hardly reduced due to the much lower reaction rate than the mesoporous surface depending on the size effect. Surprisingly, through the observation in-situ TEM characterization, the hierarchically porous silicon prefered to expand inward and shrink in the inner hollow space while the Si shell almost remained stationary during the lithiation/delithiation process (Fig. 7d), which gave rise to the stable SEI and long cycling life. The unique porous silicon delivered a high coulombic efficiency of 99.91% at 0.5 mAh cm−2 and a higher volumetric capacity of 760 mAh cm−3 than graphitic anodes. To further reduce the temperature of magnesiothermic reduction, Wang et al. [195] reported a new magnesiothermic reduction method which used the pre-blended HSiCl3 as the silicon sources to react with magnesium powder under the amine catalyst at 100 °C in the anhydrous toluene solution with the subsequent dilute acid washing of produced MgCl2 to obtain the porous silicon material. The facile method with high yield is energy-saving and avoids any dangerous reagents, which is suitable for industrially scalable production. Similar to silicon nanoparticles, the higher surface area of porous silicon leads to more contact between the active silicon surface and the electrolyte, thus forming more SEI, which reduces the coulombic efficiency. And the volume expansion of silicon will also render the instability of the SEI film to further reduce the cycling stability. Surface coating could be an effective strategy to stabilize the SEI interface and prevent the excessive side reactions, which will be emphatically discussed in Section 2.4. What’s more, the high porosity of porous silicon renders the low volumetric capacity and the structural frangibility under the industrial calendering process. The calendering process is an inevitable procedure with a huge mechanical pressure of up to 80 MPa in the industrial battery electrode fabrication to boost the electrical contact between the particles and densely pack the electrode materials for the desired volumetric capacity [196]. For the sake of enhancing the mechanical stability under the high pressure, Wang et al. [197] prepared the micro-sized nano-silicon clusters which could be regarded as a porous silicon through the microemulsion approach and then coated a silicon shell with a thickness of 200 nm on the clusters surface by CVD method. Benefiting from the robust silicon shell, the structure and shape of the porous silicon remained nearly constant without fracture after forcing the high pressure of 100 MPa and simultaneously a high volumetric capacity of 2041 mAh cm−3 was obtained. What’s more, the tap density also greatly increased from 0.47 to 0.79 g cm−3 after coating the silicon shell. As a consequence, the porous silicon structure encapsulated by a graphene cage demonstrates a high ICE of 85.6% and a stable areal capacity of 2.1 mAh cm−2 with the average coulombic efficiency of 99.7% for 100 cycles at the current density of 1.4 mA cm−2. 2.4 Silicon composite anode In the previous section, we reviewed the peculiarities, preparation methods, shortcomings and corresponding solutions of silicon materials in different dimensions. However, we have not emphasized the influences of materials compounded with silicon on the performance of silicon-based anodes. And merely constructing different silicon nanostructures or porous silicon structures to reduce the internal stress of silicon during lithiation cannot guarantee that silicon will not fracture under the conditions of prolonged cycles, high rate or high massing loading. Therefore, the silicon anode material requires compounding with additional buffer matrix or coating to accommodate the volume change of silicon. And this buffer material also needs to have good electronic conductivity and lithium ion diffusivity to ameliorate the poor rate performance of silicon-based anodes and can ensure the stable electrical contact between the anode materials and current collector during repeated charging and discharging process. What’s more, a stable and thin SEI can be formed on the surface of well-designed silicon composite anodes, especially the core–shell structure, which is vital for the high coulombic efficiency and long cyclic lifespan [116,198–200]. Various materials with different characteristics can be combined with silicon to obtain the silicon composite anodes, such as carbonaceous materials, metal oxides, metals, Si oxides, polymers. 2.4.1 Silicon and carbonaceous material compound Silicon/carbon (Si/C) composite materials have attracted extremely remarkable attention in recent years and are considered as the preferential choice of researchers to improve the electrochemical performance of silicon anodes [201–203]. Compared with silicon, carbonaceous materials have higher conductivity, which can accelerate the Li+/electrons diffusion and enhance the electrical contact of active materials in the composite anodes. Carbonaceous materials can be used as a buffer matrix to alleviate the huge volume expansion of silicon because of the good mechanical properties and small volume change during the charge/discharge process. Moreover, carbonaceous materials have the characteristics of light weight, wide sources, diverse categories, mature processes, which are also conducive to the preparation of complex Si/C composite materials at low costs. It is noteworthy that Si/C composites are far more than directly mixing silicon with carbonaceous materials through simple mechanical or chemical methods, but design varied ingenious structures (e.g., core–shell structure [204], yolk-shell structure [205], sandwich structure [206], watermelon-like structure [207], three-dimensional porous structure [208]) to maintain the structure stability, prevent the continuous generation of SEI, and provide fast Li+/electrons transport channels. Therefore, material properties and structural designs should contribute to a synergistic effect to improve the overall electrochemical performance and industrial applicability of Si/C composite anodes. Carbonaceous materials that compounded with silicon primarily include the following categories: amorphous carbon, carbon nanotubes (CNT), carbon nanofibers (CNF), graphene, graphite. Below we will briefly introduce the Si/C composite anodes from the perspective of different carbonaceous materials. Amorphous carbon is commonly coated on the surface of silicon particles as a shell layer by CVD or pyrolysis of organic precursors to form a core–shell structure (core@shell) [209], which can effectively reduce the electrochemical impedance of the silicon anode, cushion the volume expansion of silicon, prevent the contact between the electrolyte and silicon core to reduce the formation of SEI and limit the agglomeration of silicon nanoparticles [210]. Creating a certain gap between the silicon core and the carbon shell via sacrificial template to form the yolk-shell structure (yolk@void@shell) can further accommodate the volume expansion of silicon in the cavity and greatly reduce the stress of the lithiated silicon forcing on the carbon shell to prevent the shell from breakage, which give rise to a stable SEI on the surface of the carbon shell and improved the cycle stability of the anode. Besides, the organic carbon source and element doping of amorphous carbon also have a significant influence on the electrochemical performance of the electrode. Superior organic carbon sources can form uniform and dense amorphous carbon with good mechanical properties and high electrical conductivity after high-temperature pyrolysis, such as phenolic resin [211], but inferior carbon sources could produce amorphous carbon with surface defects and poor mechanical properties, which renders the continuous generation of SEI and decreased coulombic efficiency. Compared with the original carbon materials, the element-doped carbon materials have higher Li+/electronic conductivity and the introduced defects can significantly alleviate the stress of the Si/C composites during lithiation leading to a robust core–shell structure without breaking [212]. Lu et al. [213] coated polypyrrole (PPy) on the ordered mesoporous silicon (OM-Si) derived from magnesiothermic reduction of SBA-15 silica through the polyreaction of pyrrole monomer to prepare OM-Si@PPy and obtained OM-Si@nitrogen-doped amorphous carbon (NC) after the heat treatment at 700 °C for 3 h. The doped nitrogen could not only serve as electron carriers to accelerate the diffusion of electrons, but also create orderly defects to promote the insertion of lithium ions at the interface between the silicon core and the carbon shell, thus improving the rate capability. Besides, the porous silicon core and robust NC shell contribute to the structural integrity during lithiation/delithiation. The OM-Si@NC composite anode exhibited a high specific capacity of 1336 mAh g−1 with a capacity retention of 73.5% after 200 cycles at 1 A g−1. CNT is a multifunctional one-dimensional material with high electronic conductivity, superior mechanical properties and thermal stability, which can not only be used to synthesize composite electrode materials, but also can be mixed with prepared electrode materials to produce a binder-free electrode with high mass loading [136]. Jia et al. [214] coated SiO2 on the surface modified CNT to prepare the CNT@SiO2 core–shell coaxial cables and then employed microemulsion method to form the condensed CNT@SiO2 microspheres. Then, aluminothermic reduction with subsequent HCl immersing was conducted to obtain the CNT@Si microspheres. Finally, the thin and uniform CVD carbon was coated on CNT@Si microspheres to produce the hierarchical CNT@Si@C porous structures (Fig. 8 a). The flexible yarn-ball-like CNT@Si@C microsphere with well-tailored porosity showed a limited volume expansion of 44% at full lithiation which was far less than 300% of silicon and could withstand a huge pressure of ~200 MPa without fracture arising from the ultrahigh Young’s modulus of CNT and the yarn-ball-like porous structure. When mixing with graphite to achieve the practical composite electrode, the CNT@Si@C-Gr composite anode delivered a capacity retention of 92% with a high areal capacity of >2.5 mAh cm−2 for 500 cycles at 0.75 mA cm−2 and the calendered electrode with a tap density of 1.4 g cm−3 could reach a high volumetric capacity up to 930 mAh cm−3. CNF is a low-cost one-dimensional carbonaceous material with good mechanical properties and thermal stability. Si/CNF composite anode is typically fabricated into a flexible paper through electrospinning PAN solution with additive Si particles and subsequent carbonization. In such paper, CNFs produce a 3D crosslinked conductive network which offers more space for stress relaxation and rapid Li+ transport, and the Si particles can be tightly connected with the nanofibers. What’s more, the Si/CNF composite paper can be directly used as the working electrode without heavy current collector and binders, which increases the overall energy density of the electrode [215]. Wang et al. [216] dispersed aluminum acetylacetonate (AACA)-coated Si nanoparticles into the electrospinning precursor, then stabilized the obtained paper in air at 280 °C with the sublimation of AACA to create pores around the Si nanoparticles, and finally obtained the porous Si/C composite nanofibers through carbonization. The mesopores located both on the surface and around Si nanoparticles inside the nanofibers contribute to more accommodation space to decrease the induced stress of silicon during lithiation, which could utilize more reversible capacity of silicon without pulverization relative to the Si/C composite nanofibers without porous structure. And the microvoid in the nanofibers could accelerate the electrolyte transport. What’s more, the well-designed structure can enable almost all Si nanoparticles to be embedded inside the nanofibers to prevent the contact with the electrolytes and form a stable SEI. As a consequence, the Si/C composite nanofibers anode delivered an initial discharge capacity of 1639 mAh g−1 with a high ICE of 83.6% and a reversible capacity of more than 1000 mAh g−1 after 20 cycles. Graphene is a single-layer two-dimensional material with large specific surface area, high electronic conductivity, excellent mechanical properties and thermodynamic stability, which can be directly used as the anode material for LIBs exhibiting a higher theoretical capacity of 744 mAh g−1 than graphite anode [217]. In the Si/graphene composite materials, graphene has two forms of two-dimensional graphene sheet [218] and three-dimensional graphene cage [219]. Wang et al. [220] mixed the PDDA modified silicon nanoparticles with graphene to obtain the graphene/silicon nanoparticles composite (GSc), and then used styrene-butadiene latex as the carbon source to prepare the 3D free-standing graphene scaffold embedded with soft carbon coating silicon nanoparticles (GSCS) after the final thermal treatment at 500 °C (Fig. 8b). The PDDA played an important role in providing surface positive charge for silicon nanoparticles to ensure the strong attachment with graphene through electrostatic self-assembly, which contributed to the stable electrical contact of silicon nanoparticles. Besides, silicon nanoparticles could be evenly distributed on the graphene surface without agglomeration due to electrostatic repulsion. The soft carbon coating layer also works well in Si/graphene composite materials, because it relieves the stress and provides fast lithium ions diffusion channels while reducing the formation of SEI in the three-dimensional porous structure. Furthermore, the 3D graphene scaffold provided a superior continuous conductive network and sufficient buffering space, which allowed the composite material to be directly used as the working electrode and with high contents of silicon. Benefiting from the synergistic effect of soft carbon coating and graphene scaffold, the composite electrode delivered a high capacity of 1100 mAh g−1 at 2 A g−1 after 300 cycles and a practical areal capacity of 2.64 mAh cm−2 at a high current density of 1.90 mA cm−2. Compared with those one-dimensional carbonaceous materials or graphene, graphite has a smaller surface area, which can reduce the decomposition of the electrolyte and improve the ICE [222]. And good mechanical properties can greatly limit the swelling of silicon electrodes in the graphite matrix [223]. Nowadays, some Si/graphite composite materials with low contents of silicon have been commercialized because of the low cost of commercial graphite and the compatibility of manufacturing process with current battery manufacturing equipment [224]. Besides, the high tap density and volumetric energy density of graphite also compensate for the inherent defects of silicon anodes of low areal capacity. In addition, mixing with the deformable and slippery graphite is an effective strategy to improve the calendering resistance of silicon electrodes for high volumetric energy density. All the factors above make the Si/graphite composite become the most promising anode materials candidate for commercial high-energy batteries in the near future. Recently, a calendering-compatible C/Si@MPC-G composite anode with high full-cell energy density was proposed by Son et al. [221]. Firstly, a macroporous carbon (MPC) was prepared to be strongly bonded to the graphite surface via physically mixing spherical natural graphite, pitch, and SiO2 nanoparticles together in the shear mixer and the subsequent carbonization and the removal of SiO2 template by NaOH. Then, a thin Si nanolayer was deposited on the surface of MPC and exposed graphite. Finally, similar procedures of mixing the sample with pitch and the subsequent annealing were conducted to coat an amorphous carbon on the outermost surface of the MPC layer. Noticeably, ‘the outermost surface’ indicated that no carbon was coated on the inner surface of the macropores to form an enough non-filling space for the volume change of silicon, and gave rise to a low specific surface area which facilitated the improved ICE and slurry manufacturing. In addition, the macroporous structure with high surface area was conducive to depositing high contents of ultrathin Si nanolayers with smaller crystalline size, which could significantly reduce the strain induced by lithiation to maintain the structural stabilization. After calendering, the composite materials could maintain its porosity without any fracture due to the synergistic effect of the macroporous structure and the elastic carbon covering (Fig. 8c). As a result, the C/Si@MPC-G composite anode exhibited an initial capacity of 665 mAh g−1 with a high ICE of 90.9% and a high areal capacity of more than 3.6 mAh cm−2 in the half cell test. When assembling with NMC622 cathode, the full cell showed a stable cycling over 200 cycles with high energy density of 932 Wh L−1 and 333 Wh kg−1. To sum up, in Si/C composite materials, silicon increases the limited capacity of carbonaceous materials while carbonaceous materials improve the rate performance and cycle stability of Si/C composite anodes, so the weight ratio of silicon to different carbonaceous materials needs to be accurately tailored to achieve the desirable tradeoff between capacity and cycle life. More high-quality and non-toxic carbon precursors coupling with cost-efficient and scalable preparation methods like mechanical ball milling and wet processing methods need to be developed to obtain high-performance Si/C materials with low cost. Structural design and porosity engineering also deserve serious consideration to stretch the synergistic effect of Si/C composite materials with a mechanically robust structure. Besides, carbonaceous materials not only play an indispensable role in Si/C composite materials, but also can be embedded in other silicon composite electrodes to further improve the performance of silicon-based anodes. 2.4.2 Silicon and metal oxide compound Metal oxides can not only be employed directly as anode materials for LIBs with relatively high specific capacity [225], but also serve as the buffer coating layer in the Si/metal oxide composite to alleviate the volume expansion of silicon and reduce side reactions for improving the cyclic performance. The metallic oxides that could compound with silicon consist of Al2O3 [226], Co3O4 [227], indium tin oxide [228], CuO [229], etc. For instance, Li et al. [230] prepared mesoporous Si@Al2O3 nanosphere with reduced charge transfer resistance and a stable SEI layer, showing a specific capacity of 1001.7 mAh g−1 at 2 A g−1 after 500 cycles. Wang et al. [231] synthesized Si@Fe2O3/C derived from Si@metal–organic-frameworks and the metallic Fe generated through lithiation of Fe2O3 greatly enhanced the electrode kinetics, delivering a reversible capacity of 680.7 mAh g−1 at 1 A g−1 after 300 cycles. Among all metal oxides, TiO2 is the most promising and outstanding candidate to replace carbonaceous coating. The introduction of TiO2 coating onto silicon nanostructures has the following characteristics. (1) The high lithiation potential of TiO2 (1.5–1.8 V) renders less SEI deposition, so higher ICE can be obtained compared to amorphous carbon and graphite [232]. (2) Lithiated TiO2 has only a small volume change of <4% and TiO2 possesses good mechanical strength, which can maintain the structural stability of the silicon-based material during charge and discharge process. (3) The SEI formed on Si@TiO2 has good thermal stability, which can increase the onset temperature of the violent exothermic reaction due to electrolyte deposition from ~230 °C of carbon shell to ~285 °C of amorphous TiO2 Shell, indicating the enhanced safety of the battery [233]. (4) Although TiO2 is a semiconductor material with inherently low conductivity, its Li+/electron diffusivity will undergo tremendous changes with lithiation state, crystal type and the introduction of oxygen vacancy. For example, the lithiated TiO2 and nonstoichiometric TiO2− x [234] both have a higher electronic conductivity. Besides, the TiO2 shell with a thickness of less than 5 nm has a high Li+/electron conductivity due to size-dependent transport [235,236] and could induce a typical pseudocapacitive effect which enable fast Li+ insertion near the surface at ultrahigh rate [237]. All these factors contribute to high ion/electron accessibility to the Si core. (5) Yang et al. [233] presented that in the ordinary core–shell structure, the amorphous TiO2 shell showed better performance than the anatase TiO2 shell, because amorphous TiO2 shell has good mechanical properties with elastic behavior and more open active diffusion channel, which can release the stress and maintain the structural integrity without pulverization in the prolonged cycles. This paragraph will be an exploration of the Si@TiO2 composite anodes, which not only demonstrates the superiority of TiO2 coating, but also leads us to deeply understand the importance of stress relaxation strategies and stable SEI for silicon-based anodes. Lu et al. [238] synthesized the hollow silicon nanospheres through self-assembly approach in the CTAB solution with the subsequent magnesiothermic reduction, and then successively coated TiO2 and amorphous carbon on the surface of nanospheres via a one-step sol–gel method to obtain the hollow core-dual shell structure (hollow silicon@TiO2@C). The hollow silicon nanospheres with the robust TiO2 coating make the silicon expand into inner cavities with sufficient space and relieve the mechanical stress to maintain the structural stability without silicon pulverization during the charging/discharging process. The outer carbon layer not only significantly improves the overall electronic and ionic conductivity, but also further restrains the expansion of the inner silicon core to produce a stable SEI film on the surface of the nanosphere. The hollow silicon core, TiO2 shell and carbon shell are tightly connected together, which provides rapid charge transfer channels to improve the rate capability, exhibiting the superiority relative to the yolk-shell structure with void space which could increase the charge transfer resistance [239]. Through FE-SEM, a less electrode swelling rate of 45.6% with smooth surface was observed for the hollow silicon@TiO2@C anode after 250 cycles. And the composite anode delivered an initial discharge capacity of 2557.1 mAh g−1 with a high ICE of 86.06% and a reversible capacity of 1058.3 mAh g−1 at a high current density of 4 A g−1 after 400 cycles. Jin et al. [240] revealed an intriguing and powerful self-healing function of yolk-shell Si@TiO2 structure. The Si@void@TiO2 clusters were prepared by successively growing uniform carbon layer and TiO2 on the commercial Si nanoparticles and calcination at 550 °C in air to remove the intermediate carbon layer and form many anatase shells connected together. The TiO2 shell and amorphous carbon shell both could be regarded as the artificial SEI (aSEI), because they prevent the penetration of electrolyte and facilitate the formation of a relatively stable natural SEI (nSEI) on their surfaces. However, during the preparation process of yolk-shell structure or the subsequent calendering process, this aSEI is inevitably not completely enclosed or partially broken, so the electrolyte will rush into the shell and react with silicon to produce a large amount of fragile nSEI which is greatly responsible for the low coulombic efficiency of silicon-based anodes. Whereas, during the first lithiation process, the silicon core expands to eject the electrolyte and brings the newly formed nSEI into contact with the inner surface of the TiO2 shell to bond with the nSEI on the outer TiO2 shell and TiO2 shells to repair partial cracks. After about 10 cycles, a hermetically sealed shell of aSEI + nSEI will be finally formed to isolate the electrolyte from contact with silicon (Fig. 9 a). And TiO2 shell has more powerful and rapid self-healing function than amorphous carbon shell because of its better adhesion to SEI. Moreover, owing to the 5 times mechanical strength of the TiO2 shell than amorphous carbon shell, the TiO2 shell can withstand the load applied by the silicon core without breakage even when the void is not large enough, and the strength of the entire structure can also sustain the industrial calendering process up to 160 MPa. Even though some TiO2 shells will be broken under high pressure, the structural integrity can be achieved again through self-healing. Furthermore, the TiO2 shell layer can attain rapid charging at 45–60 C indicating the excellent contact between the silicon core and TiO2 shell, which all demonstrate superiority to traditional carbon coatings and are extremely attractive for practical applications. After pressing high pressure which is the easiest way to overcome the shortcomings of low tap density of silicon nanomaterials, the coulombic efficiency of many cycles can reach more than 99.99% or even 100% after 300 cycles in the half cell test, which is rare for Si-based anodes and signify the high-performance and perfectly hermitic TiO2 shell. When matching a commercial lithium cobalt oxide cathode with an areal capacity of 3 mAh cm−2 to form a practical full battery, the Si@void@TiO2 anode with a high tap density of 2.1 mg cm−3 delivered a stable areal capacity of 1.6 mAh cm−2 at 0.7 mA cm−2 for 100 cycles with a high volumetric capacity of 980 mAh cm−3. Shi et al. [241] prepared the micron-sized self-assembled hierarchical Si@TiO2@C (SA-SiTC) which comprised numerous Si@TiO2 nanospheres tightly connected in the carbon framework through microemulsion approach and sol–gel method. A huge stress gradient change arising from the point-point contact between Si nanostructures is easy to cause crack during deep lithiation, so a finite element model was simulated to control the stress evolution between multiple particles in the hierarchical architecture. As the carbon framework can effectively increase the contact area between nanospheres and the stiff TiO2 layer further relieves the volume change, the simulation result exhibited that the outer hoop stress of SA-SiTC is reduced by 0.53 times in contrast to the monodispersed Si@TiO2@C nanoparticle and the stress gradient change is little near the area of point-point contact, indicating the uniformly distributed stress in the hierarchical structure which could maintain the structural integrity without particle breakage (Fig. 9b). Besides, the micron-sized hierarchical architecture could also greatly enhance the tap density, quickly release the strain at high rate and form a stale SEI on the SA-SiTC surface. As a consequence, the SA-SiTC anode presented a high specific capacity of 842.6 mAh g−1 at 2 A g−1 after prolonged 1000 cycles and a reversible capacity of 823 mAh g−1 at a high current density of 6 A g−1. The LCO|SA-SiTC full cell delivered a large energy density of 339.9 Wh kg−1 after 100 cycles and a little electrode swelling rate of 15% after 150 cycles. This work signifies that the finite element simulation model can be a powerful tool to calculate the stress distribution, the formation of lithium-silicon alloy phase and the evolution of SEI film for guiding the rational design of silicon-based nanostructures or microstructures in the future. Although metal oxides are earth-abundant, their precursors as coating materials are still relatively expensive organic compounds or metal salts. More simple synthesis methods with cost-efficient precursors are urgently desired for practical preparation. Moreover, most metal oxides usually undergo severe volume changes during lithiation and poor electronic conductivity, so further modification or compound Si@metal oxide with other functional materials are the feasible pathways for enhancing the electrochemical performance of Si/metal oxide composite anodes. 2.4.3 Silicon and metal compound The combination of silicon and metal is another feasible and extensively investigated strategy to improve the electrochemical performance of silicon electrodes. The highly conductive metal dispersed in the silicon matrix can provide an excellent conductive network to significantly improve the rate performance. And the high mechanical strength with good ductility can allow metal materials to be used as structural supports to inhibit volume expansion and prevent silicon particles from agglomerating. Si/metal composite anodes could be synthesized in three typical forms of Si-metal alloys of different dimensions, core–shell structure and Si nanoparticles/Si microparticles/porous Si modified with metal nanoparticles. The metal materials compounded with silicon can be divided into Li-active materials which contribute to capacity (e.g., Mg [242], Zn [243], Ge [244]) and Li-inert materials which do not alloy with lithium during cycling (e.g., Cu [245], Fe [246], Co [247]). Ruttert et al. [246] simply synthesized Si/Fe-Si alloy material by mechanochemically ball milling micron-sized Si and Fe powder in the Ar atmosphere and researched the effect of different factors on the electrochemical performance of Si/metal composite anodes. In this experiment, the milling duration should be long enough to ensure that Fe was completely converted into advantageous α-FeSi2 phase. Fe and Fe-Si alloy own high mass density, which could significantly increase the tap density of nano-Si for a high volumetric energy density. And the weld of particles formed in the ball milling process renders low specific surface areas, which causes less SEI formation and improved ICE > 90%. The Si/Fe-Si with higher content of Si showed higher ICE and initial discharge capacity accompanying with poor capacity retention. After adding 5 wt% graphite in the optimized second ball milling, the sample exhibited a high initial discharge capacity of 1375 mAh g−1 with a high ICE of 89.2% and a capacity retention of 78% after 100 cycles. When assembling with NCM-111 to obtain the full cell, the Fe25Si75 sample delivered a high energy density of 289 Wh kg−1 with the coulombic efficiency of 99.6% after 150 cycles, while the commercial Si/C anode can only reach energy density of ~120 Wh kg−1 with the coulombic efficiency of 99.0%, indicating the enhanced cycling performance of the Si/Fe-Si alloy anode arising from the inactive Fe x Si y phase. Zhang et al. [248] prepared the Cu segments core-Si/Ge bilayer shell nanowires architecture (Cu/Si/Ge NW) on the porous Ni foam via successive sputtering of Si and Ge on the CuO nanowires with the subsequent reduction of CuO at 300 °C in Ar/H2. Ge is an alloy anode material for LIBs with a theoretical capacity of 1384 mAh g−1 and shows 400 times the Li diffusivity and 1000 times the electrical conductivity of silicon [249]. However, Ge materials are too expensive for practical applications. So compounding Ge with low-cost Si could be a feasible method to significantly improve the electrode kinetics in contrast to the pure Si anode while maintaining the high capacity. Not only can copper be used as a robust and conductive support, but the enlarged internal space between Cu segments during lithiation can accommodate the inward expansion of silicon to suppress the structural breakage. Except for the superiorities of nanoscale and nanowire arrays to accommodate the volume change, the effect of dynamic co-lithiation/co-delithiation in the Si/Ge bilayer shell was conducted by in-situ TEM and chemomechanical modeling, which demonstrated that the pernicious hoop tensile deformation generated on the Ge surface due to the lithiation of both Si and Ge could be reduced to some extent by the electrochemical lithiation in the outer Ge layer. Besides, the high electronic/ionic conductivity derived from the Cu core and Ge shell contributes to more uniform lithiation, which further decreases the mechanical stress to maintain the structural stability during cycling. As a result, the Cu/Si/Ge NW anode can deliver a high specific capacity of 1523 mAh g−1 at a high current density of 4 A g−1 with the capacity retention of 81% after a prolonged 3000 cycles, while the Cu/Si anode could only reach 745 mAh g−1with a capacity retention of 48%. Xi et al. [250] employed Cu-assisted chemical etching and ball-milled metallurgical grade silicon as the precursor to prepare silicon nanoparticles with high purity of 99.97% and then used silver-assisted chemical etching to further etch the silicon surface to produce porous silicon embedded with silver nanoparticles in the holes without an extra acid wash for the pSi/Ag composite anode. The Ag nanoparticles uniformly distributed in the porous matrix can provide rapid electronic transport channels through the silicon interior to improve the rate capability and the sufficient void space could accommodate the volume change during cycling to sustain the electrode stability. The pSi/Ag anode achieved a high initial discharge capacity of 2757 mAh g−1 with a high ICE of 89.09% at 1 A g−1 and could maintain the capacity of 1930 mAh g−1 after 50 cycles. After integrating with RGO, the composite anode delivered a stable capacity of more than 1000 mAh g−1 after 200 cycles at 0.5 A g−1. Although the silicon/metal composite material can enhance the conductivity and cyclic stability of the electrode compared to the original silicon electrode, it has the defects of heavy quality, high cost of raw material, complex production process, and difficult control of structure and morphology. Moreover, its reversible capacity and cyclic performance under high areal mass loading and high rate still need to be improved. 2.4.4 Silicon and other materials compound A natural SiO x layer is usually formed on the surface of silicon particles due to exposure to the air or water, and it is also a high-capacity anode material with less volume change than Si during lithiation/delithiation [251]. The SiO x material is insulating until lithiated and the lithiation SiO x still shows lower conductivity than Si, so the SiO x coating on the Si surface cannot be thick. Guo et al. [252] prepared Si@SiO x nanoparticles decorated by surface SiOH groups via ultrasonic dispersion Si nanoparticles in aqueous solution for few days and the thickness of SiO x layer can be controlled by reaction duration. The lithium silicates and Li2O generated from the lithiation of SiO x function as the buffer layer to alleviate the volume change and the SiOH groups on the Si@SiO x surface can react with conductive agent to form a strong covalent bonds for a tight electrical contact, which both give rise to long cycle life. The Si@SiO x with optimal SiO x thickness of 2 nm showed the best electrochemical performance due to the highest Li diffusion coefficient and less Si4+ generation, delivering a high initial discharge capacity of 4361 mAh g−1 with the ICE of 82.1% and the speicific capacity of 1128 mAh g−1 at 1 A g−1 after 500 cycles. Polymer materials with high flexibility and chemical stability are widely used as the binder in the anode slurry process, and endowing the polymer with additional properties, such as electrical conductivity and self-healing properties, can further improve the electrochemical performance of silicon anodes. Meanwhile, the polymer can also be conformally coated on the surface of the silicon particles, which can further enhance the electrical contact with the silicon particles and form continuous electronic transport channels. Wu et al. [253] employed in-situ polymerization reaction with the assist of ammonium persulfate initiator and phytic acid to intimately coat polyaniline (PANi) on the surface of Si nanoparticles with 3D crosslinked polyaniline conductive network. The viscous gel can be directly coated on the Cu current collector without binder and conductive agent. The porous conductive framework can not only offer fast ionic/electronic transport channel, but also accommodate the huge volume expansion during cycling. Even if the silicon particles were broken during a long cycle, they would still be confined in the polyaniline coating and maintain good electrical contact. Besides, the SEI formed on the polyaniline was thin, deformable and stable. Therefore, a high capacity retention of 91% after 5000 cycles at a high current density of 6 A g−1 was achieved, delivering a reversible capacity of 550 mAh g−1 and a volumetric capacity of 1080 mAh cm−3. In general, the well-designed silicon composite anode overcomes various shortcomings of pure silicon anodes, such as low conductivity, huge volume expansion and unstable SEI, which greatly promotes the development of silicon anodes and commercialization process, especially Si/graphite composite anodes. Carbonaceous materials will still be the research hotspot of silicon composite anode materials, not only due to the lower production costs and abundant precursors, but also because carbonaceous materials can be conveniently combined with other silicon composite materials to further improve their electrochemical performance. Although the materials composited with silicon contributes to the enhanced conductivity and cycle stability, they typically possess low theoretical capacity or do not contribute to the capacity, so the weight ratio of silicon to composite materials must be seriously tailored under consideration of the trade-off between high capacity and long cycle life. In the future, more researches on silicon composite anode materials could be focused on further exploring the surface engineering of silicon anodes, synthesizing polynary composites with the optimal synergistic effects and seeking novel materials to compound with silicon for the unexpected improvements of overall electrochemical performance. 2.5 Lithium metal anode At present, compared with the booming development of computer industry and smart electronic devices, the growth rates of energy densities of LIBs are seriously lagging behind [17]. And it is foreseeable that traditional LIBs with intercalation type cathodes (such as LiFePO4, LiCoO2, LiNi1− x − y Co x Mn y O2) and insertion-host anodes (as opposed to hostless lithium metal anodes, such as C, Li4Ti5O12, Si) will reach their energy density limitations in the near future due to the absence of new high-voltage and high-capacity electrode materials. Even the up-to-date LIBs with Si-based anodes and high-capacity cathodes seem to only reach ~300 Wh kg−1 of cell-level energy [254,255]. Therefore, for the sake of attaining a qualitative leap in the energy density of rechargeable lithium batteries, we must substantially upgrade the current lithium battery system to exceed Li-ion chemistry [256]. Lithium metal, with ultrahigh theoretical capacity of 3860 mAh g−1 and lowest negative electrochemical potential of −3.04 V vs. the standard hydrogen electrode, is considered as the “Holy Grail” anode for energy storage systems [257,258]. More importantly, lithium metal can be paired with non-lithium cathodes (such as S, O2, CO2) to form the new-generation LMBs, which exhibit superior theoretical energy densities of 3505 Wh kg−1 for Li-O2 batteries and 2600 Wh kg−1 for Li-S batteries [259,260]. Besides, lithium metal anode can also be assembled with the mature lithium transition-metal oxide cathode to deliver a specific energy of ~440 Wh kg−1 [261]. Before the commercialization of these revolutionary technologies, two critical issues of lithium metal anodes need to be figured out: low security and short cycle life. Due to the uneven lithium deposition on the surface of the pristine lithium metal, lithium dendrites will be generated and grow vertically to eventually pierce the separator and contact the positive electrode, thereby causing the short circuit of the battery [262]. Meanwhile, serious safety accidents may be rendered by the occurrence of thermal runaway and explosion. What’s more, the high surface area of the lithium dendrites contributes to the consumption of more active lithium and electrolyte, and the lithium dendrites wrapped by the dense SEI are converted into dead lithium arising from the loss of electrical contact with the current collector, which will both lead to the low coulombic efficiency and short cyclic lifespan [263,264]. The porous surface morphology with messy lithium dendrites hinders the transmission of lithium ions or electrons and increases the impedance, which also leads to huge voltage polarization [265]. In addition, lithium metal is a conversion anode without a host to accommodate the plating of lithium ions, thus its volume expansion is extremely huge, even surpassing the silicon anode. Such structural instability will also result in low security [17]. 2.5.1 Lithium dendrites growth To fully realize the superior performance of LMBs with security, effective measures must be taken to alleviate or even eliminate the growth of dendrites. For this reason, it is essential to understand how dendrites are generated and grown. The growth of lithium dendrites could be generally divided into three stages (Fig. 10 ) [266]. (1) SEI formation: As a highly reactive metal, when the lithium metal is in contact with the electrolyte, it will immediately react with the electrolyte to produce a SEI. This passivation layer prevents lithium from continuing side reaction. However, the SEI film is naturally inhomogeneous and fragile. The pinholes and defects in the SEI film breed the nucleation sites for further dendrites growth. Due to the high-priority of SEI formation relative to Li deposition behavior [267], the next stage will be the stimulated Li plating process between the SEI film and the lithium substrate. (2) Dendrites nucleation: During the Li plating process, a number of Li nuclei form on the Li electrode surface and the early growth of nuclei breaks the fragile SEI. The fractured SEI not only render extra electrolyte consumption, but also trigger more heterogeneous lithium precipitation owing to the increased ion flux [268]. And eventually will occur the final stage—dendrites growth. (3) Dendrites growth: After dendrites nucleation, the hemispherical nuclei will grow into forked cylindrical lithium dendrites along the length direction and sometimes diameter direction, exhibiting various typical morphologies such as needlelike dendrites, mosslike dendrites and treelike dendrites [17]. The rough visualization of lithium dendrites formation leaves much to be desired. The theoretical researches on the electrochemistry mechanism of Li deposition behavior, especially the nucleation and early growth period, enable us to attain a deeper understanding and propose the corresponding solutions to suppress or even eliminate lithium dendrites. So far, several models explaining the nucleation and early growth process of lithium dendrites have been proposed, including the space-charge model, surface diffusion model, heterogeneous nucleation model, crystallography model and stress-driven dendrite growth model. The space-charge model presents that during the rapid Li plating process in dilute solution, when the concentration of lithium ions decreases sharply to zero, a dendritic structure will be triggered by a large space charge on the surface of lithium metal [269]. The critical time of initial dendrite growth can be evaluated by Sand’s time [270]: (5) τ s = π D C 0 e Z c 2 J 2 μ a + μ c μ a 2 , where μ is the initial time of Li dendrites growth, D is diffusion coefficient, C 0 is the initial cationic concentration, Z c is the charge number of cations, μ a and μ c are the anionic and cationic mobility, J is effective electrode current density. It can be seen from the equation that Sand’s time can be extended by increasing the anionic and Li+ mobility or uniformize electrode current density, which provides fundamental knowledge for the design of electrode structure and electrolyte to suppress the dendrites growth. The surface diffusion model stems from the comparison of deposition morphology between Li metal battery and Mg metal battery [271]. A density function theory research reveals that the smaller free energy difference of Li metal originating from weaker Li–Li bond renders lithium accumulating in a certain site and depositing to form one-dimensional dendrites instead of diffusing around to form high-dimensional uniform precipitation like Mg [272]. Therefore, lithium dendrites are easier to generate under the condition of lower surface energy and higher diffusion barrier. This model provides guidelines for the design of electrolyte components, electrolyte additives and artificial SEI to form main SEI components with higher surface energy and lower diffusion barriers. Ely et al. [273] put forward the heterogeneous nucleation model through thermodynamical and kinetical simulation to describe the initial nucleation process and divide the nucleation process into five regimes: nucleation suppression regime, long incubation time regime, short incubation time regime, early growth regime and late growth regime. The thermodynamically stable Li nuclei survive the first two stages and the nuclei with critical diameter start growing to a more uniform size under certain overpotentials. Then the thermodynamically and kinetically stable Li nuclei grow to the ultimate size at a uniform velocity in the final two stages. This model motivates the rational design for the current collector and 3D matrix of the lithium electrode to regulate the nucleation sites and guide the growth behavior under the consideration of limiting the Li nuclei size in the electrode skeleton and improve the lithiophilicity [274]. The crystallography model elucidates that single-crystalline lithium nanowires primarily grow along the <111> direction and expose the {110} face as the side wall owing to the decreased surface energy of Li plating [275], hence seeking a host to control the growth direction along the <110> or <211> direction could help suppress the dendrites growth and adjust the deposition morphology. However, this model needs to be optimized because dendritics growth usually presents various disorderly morphology rather than the growth of single crystal nanowires. The stress-driven dendrite growth model [276] points out that when the Li filament growth rate (ν growth) is greater than the uniform deposition rate (ν deposition), dendrites will be generated, and ν growth corresponds to the compressive stress (σ): (6) v d e p o s i t i o n = jV L i F , (7) v g r o w t h = D L i V L i σ RTr , where j is the plating current density, V Li is Li molar volume, F is Faraday’s constant, D Li is the effective diffusion rate of Li in the Li layer, and r is the filament radius. Based on the new model, dendrite elimination strategies could be figured out via mitigating the mechanical residual force. A critical stress could be calculated under certain condition as the stress-relieving goal for the dendrite-free morphology, which will be an intriguing research topic for advanced LMBs in the future. In the light of the state-of-the-art understanding of Li deposition mechanism, following strategies have been proposed to inhibit uncontrollable dendrite growth and relieve volume fluctuations of the lithium metal anode for safe LMBs with excellent electrochemical performance: electrolyte additives for stable SEI [277,278], artificial SEI [279,280], solid-state electrolyte [281] and new structured anode material design [282]. 2.5.2 Stable SEI formed by electrolyte additives Adding additives to the liquid electrolyte is a simple and economical method to inhibit the growth of lithium dendrites and improve the coulombic efficiency. A good additive should possess a higher occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) and a lower unoccupied molecular orbital (LOMO) than electrolyte to ensure preferentially reacting with lithium metal to form an electrochemically stable and dense SEI layer during the initial activation cycles, which could prevent the decomposition of the electrolyte in the following cycles and even greatly reduce the decomposition of fractional lithium salts or solvents in the initial cycles [283]. The dense and smooth SEI film provides rapid Li+ channels and homogenizes the Li+ flux, thus retarding the growth of lithium dendrites. The electrolyte additives for stable SEI can be divided into inorganic additives and organic additives. The typical inorganic additives consist of three types: acidic gas, inorganic acids, metal salts, such as CO2 [284], boric acid (BA) [285], LiNO3 [286]. He et al. [287] reported that LiClO4 which was considered as the main electrolyte salt for LIBs could be an effective electrolyte additive to improve the coulombic efficiency and cyclic lifespan for LMBs. Unlike other electrolyte additives, LiClO4 acts as a catalyst to facilitate the full decomposition of electrolyte salts LiTFSI for obtaining an optimized SEI component with more LiF and Li2S, which contributes to the enhanced Li+ transmission. Meanwhile, LiClO4 will not be consumed during the lithium plating process and the Li-Cu cell with 7% LiClO4 exhibits increased cycling lifespan over 95 cycles in the carbonate electrolyte, which overcome the weakness of most sacrificial electrolytes, such as LiNO3. Another type of additives is organic additives, of which fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC) and vinylene carbonate (VC) [288] are commercially applied in rechargeable lithium batteries. Zhang et al. [289] introduced the FEC additives into the carbonate electrolyte to form LiF-rich SEI, which inhibit the side reactions between solvents and Li metal and enhance the Li+ diffusion. The dense and uniform morphology was obtained with largely reduced dead Li and Li dendrites. With 5% FEC electrolyte, the Li | Cu half cell presented the coulombic efficiency of 98% and low polarization of 50 mV within 100cycles, and the full cell assembled with high loading NMC cathode (12 mg cm−2) delivered a high initial capacity of 154 mAh g−1 with no obvious capacity drop for 100 cycles at 1.0 C. However, most electrolyte additives will be totally consumed or lose efficacy during the prolonged cycles due to the low modulus and structural instability of formed SEI, which is not easy to deal with. Further researches could focus on improving the ionic conductivity of the inorganic SEI components, optimizing the synergistic effect of dual-salts additives [290] and exploring the underlying mechanism of electrolyte additives on SEI for a design principle. 2.5.3 Artificial SEI The SEI formed by the reaction between lithium metal and electrolyte during the cycling process is customarily unstable in physical structure and chemical composition [291]. During the prolonged cycles, the SEI will fracture and regenerate due to the inability to withstand the volume change of lithium and the growth of lithium dendrites, even after introducing electrolyte additives, which continues to consume active lithium and electrolyte and shortens cyclic lifespan [283]. Furthermore, the uncontrollable decomposition of the electrolyte renders the inhomogeneity of the chemical components and spatial distribution of the in-situ SEI, leading to uneven lithium ion flux and lithium deposition, ultimately the formation of lithium dendrites [292]. Optimizing the in-situ SEI also has difficulty due to the complexity and limited understanding of its chemical components [293]. In such a context, the researchers proposed to uniformly coat an artificial protective layer on the lithium metal anode by physical or chemical methods in advance. The artificial coating has high ionic conductivity and electronic insulation to ensure that the lithium metal can be uniformly deposited underneath the protective layer. And the coating is chemically or electrochemically stable, so that it neither reacts with the electrolyte nor with the lithium metal during the cycling process, which could be considered as an artificial SEI [279]. High Young’s modulus and flexibility are also significant factors of the artificial SEI to mechanically suppress the growth of lithium dendrites and relieve the fluctuation of lithium metal [294]. Various organic, inorganic and alloy materials with specific peculiarities have been explored as an artificial SEI to facilitate the uniform deposition of lithium metal and improve the electrochemical performance of lithium metal anodes, such as PDMS [295], Li3PO4 [296], reduced graphene oxide [297], Li-Al [298]. Lin et al. [299] employed a convenient method of heating the lithium foil and iodine powder in a sealed quartz reactor to fabricate a uniform and dense protective layer on the lithium metal surface. The LiI layer exhibited higher Li+ conductivity than the natural SEI layer and could maintain the stability during the repeated plating process, which contribute to an efficient electrode/electrolyte interface and a dendrite-free morphology. The obtained Li-LiI symmetrical cell could run steadily for 700 h at 1 mA cm−2 with the areal capacity of 1 mAh cm−2 and the Li-LiI full cell assembled with NCM523 cathode showed the excellent capacity retention of 74.6% after 500 cycles at 2 C. The artificial SEI containing a single component presents certain limitations due to the nature of the material. For example, lithium compounds own high mechanical modulus and fast lithium ions transport, but their flexibility still needs to be further improved. Constructing a multifunctional artificial SEI with different components enable utilizing their strengths and making up for their weaknesses to reach an excellent synergetic effect. Liu et al. [300] soaked the lithium metal in the polyphosphoricester (PPE) solution to produce an inorganic/organic dual-layered film adhering to the lithium metal. The PPE molecules close to the surface of the lithium metal will spontaneously react with lithium to form an inorganic Li3PO4 layer, and then the remaining outer PPE molecules will be absorbed onto the inorganic layer to generate an uniform organic layer with the succeeding evaporation process. The flexible organic layer with low Young’s modulus of 550 MPa could accommodate the volumetric change of lithium during the cycling, while the stiff inorganic layer with high Young’s modulus of 12 GPa was strong enough to hinder the growth of lithium dendrites. The synergistic effect and high ionic conductivity contribute to the long cyclic stability and dendrite-free surface morphology. The obtained PPE-Li/LiFePO4 full cell exhibited the capacity retention of 83.2% for 300 cycles at the current density of 170 mA g−1. In a word, the well-designed artificial SEI is an effective and promising strategy to suppress the lithium dendrites growth and regulate the Li deposition behavior. However, the degradation of artificial SEI is irreversible because it cannot be restored during battery operation. Therefore, we not only need to improve the manufacturing quality and accuracy of the protective layer, but also need to research the mechanism of artificial SEI to optimize its components and properties. For example, how the various components of the composite coating affect each other, and how the ideal properties (high shear modulus, superior ionic conductivity, excellent flexibility) can be combined to achieve the best synergistic effect. The thickness of the coatings should also be considered, which is not just because the thickness will affect the performance, but because excessively thick artificial SEI will reduce the energy density of the anode. In addition, the development of the convenient and economical methods for the large-scale production of artificial SEI will still be a hot topic for the practical application of advanced LMBs. 2.5.4 Solid-state electrolyte Replacing liquid electrolyte with solid-state electrolyte (SSE) is supposed to be a state-of-the-art strategy to solve the safety issues of rechargeable lithium batteries including flammability, leakage risk and chemical instability [301,302]. For LMBs, the good mechanical properties and chemical stability of SSE can effectively suppress the lithium dendrites growth and reduce the side reactions in the Li/electrolyte interface [303,304]. The solid-state electrolyte (SSE) consists of two major categories: inorganic solid electrolytes (ISEs) and solid polymer electrolytes (SPEs). ISEs have the characteristics of high ionic conductivity, wide electrochemical window, high thermal stability and high shear modulus, but the brittleness and high interfacial resistance arising from the insufficient solid/solid contact limit the application for all-solid-state LMBs [305]. While SPEs have the excellent flexibility, but suffer from the intrinsic low ionic conductivity at room temperature [306]. Two efficient strategies will be discussed in the following sections: anion immobilization and structural reinforcement, which are motivated by SSE to facilitate the uniform lithium deposition and supress the lithium dendrites growth. According to Chazalviel’s model [269], lithium dendrites can be induced by a huge space charge arising from the anion depletion on the surface of anode. And anion immobilization strategy was validated for eliminating the space charge and homogenizing the Li+ distribution [266]. The Li+ transference number ( t L i + ) is the critical parameter, which is defined as the ratio of transferred Li+ charge to the total charge. The higher t L i + means more immobilized anions. For example, in contrast to SSE, liquid electrolyte has lower t L i + due to the numerous free anions [307]. Therefore, seeking methods for anion immobilization are effective solutions to remit the lithium dendrites formation in the SSE, such as fixing anions on the polymer backbones [308], introducing inorganic fillers into the polymer matrix [309]. Zhao et al. [310] dispersed garnet-type inorganic ceramic particles into the polymer-Li salt matrix to construct a LLZTO/PEO-LiTFSI solid-state electrolyte. The interconnected structure and chemical interactions between inorganic fillers and polymer matrix rendered fast Li+ transport and fixed TFSI− anions. The composite electrolyte with 40% LLZTO exhibited relatively higher t L i + of 0.58 than SSE without inorganic fillers ~0.37 and conventional liquid electrolyte ~0.27. As a result, the uniform Li+ distribution and smooth Li surface were obtained, and the full cell assembled with LFP cathode delivered a high capacity retention of 87% with a coulombic efficiency of 99% at 0.1 C after 100 cycles. The employment of single-component SSE is unsatisfactory for the practical application of solid-state LMBs. The well-designed blend between ISEs and SPEs can achieve a synergistic effect of structural reinforcement to obtain a composite SSE with excellent mechanical properties of high shear modulus and flexibility, which is conducive to inhibiting the lithium dendrites growth and ameliorating the interfacial stability. The structural reinforcement can be implemented via three methods of infiltrating the SPEs into 3D inorganic network [311], asymmetric organic–inorganic dual-layered SSE [312], introducing the transition layer with outstanding mechanical properties [313]. Wang et al. [314] inserted an uniform and amorphous Li phosphorous oxynitride (LiPON) film as a transition layer between the lithium metal and poly(ethylene oxide) (PEO)-Li1.5Al0.5Ge1.5(PO4)3 (LAGP) composite SSE. The LiPON film possesses a much higher shear modulus of 31 GPa relative to the 3.4 GPa of Li metal and a high elastic modulus of 77 GPa to contact closely with Li metal during the cycling process, which will effectively inhibit the Li dendrites formation. Furthermore, the good elasticity of PEO-LAGP and LiPON can keep a stable interface contact and prevent the side reactions between LAGP and Li metal. The as-obtained all-solid-state Li/LiPON5/LAGP-PEO(LiTFSI)/LiFePO4 cell can deliver an initial discharge capacity of 152.4 mAh g−1 at 0.2 C and maintain the coulombic efficiency of 100% for 100 cycles. Although SSE can effectively protect the lithium metal anode and ameliorate the safety of LMBs, the room temperature ionic conductivity is still lower than that of traditional liquid electrolytes, and the interfacial contact issues still exist on the cathode/anode surface, which cannot meet the requirements for fast-charging in the modern society. For advanced ISEs, the high mechanical strength and ionic conductivity are feasible, but their brittleness and large density are not conducive to the development of flexible high-energy LMBs. By contrast, SPEs have the characteristics of light-weight, low cost and good expandability. Thus, modifying SPEs with different polymer chains or functional materials and researching the transport mechanism of Li+ in composite SSE are promising strategies to obtain SSE with overall desired peculiarities. In addition, overcoming the challenges of the production process to manufacture SSE with a thickness of less than 10 μm without the loss of mechanical properties is also significant to increase the ionic transport kinetics and energy density of LMBs [301]. 2.5.5 New structured anode material design The aforementioned three strategies primarily apply to the electrolyte and SEI to physically restrict the growth of lithium dendrites from the external factors without changing the effective current density and Li plating/stripping process on the internal lithium metal to fundamentally control and inhibit the growth of lithium dendrites. In addition, the “infinite” volume expansion arising from the characteristic of hostless conversion anode and disorderly deposition morphology will lead to fracture and regeneration of SEI, resulting in additional electrolyte consumption and low coulombic efficiency. Therefore, the ingenious design of structured lithium metal anode material is a noteworthy and powerful patheway to accommodate the bulk expansion of lithium metal and improve the electrochemical performance of lithium metal anode [257]. Lithium foil is the most commonly used counter electrode in the lithium battery test, and it is also the prime commercial anode material for LMBs. However, many problems emerged in the practical applications, such as safety hazards caused by lithium dendrites and short cycle life. The modifications for the lithium metal material itself are the prior strategies coming to researches’ mind. Heine et al. [315] fabricated lithium powder electrodes by pressing coated lithium powder on the copper current collector foil. Due to the much higher surface area of lithium powder electrode relative to lithium foil electrode, the effective current density is significantly decreased on the anode surface, and the coated lithium powder electrode exhibit higher coulombic efficiency and lower overpotential during plating/stripping process. At the same current density, the lithium powder electrode generates less lithium dendrites or even shows dendrite-free morphology at the low current density. Directly fabricating micro-pattern on the lithium foil is another effective strategy to modify the lithium metal anode. Ryou et al. [316] employed micro-needle rolling technology to achieve a lithium metal anode with an array of square sink hole on the whole surface. The micron-sized holes increase the active surface area and provide preferred sites to control the lithium deposition process, which leads to improved electrochemical property and reduced charge transfer resistance compared to the pristine lithium foil. Although the modification techniques for the lithium metal material itself possess the advantages of simple manufacturing process and low cost, the lithium storage performance and surface morphology will deteriorate under a long cycling process or high current density. By contrast, compositing lithium metal with functional matrix could be an effective approach to accommodating the volume fluctuations of lithium and regulating the lithium deposition morphology [317,318]. Recently, some new structured three-dimensional framework for composite lithium metal anodes have been designed with the following advantages [257]. (1) The structured three-dimensional frameworks have more active surface area arising from much higher specific surface area. By endowing the active surfaces with a range of properties such as conductivity and lithiophilicity, the local current density, concentration distribution of lithium ions and nucleation overpotential can be effectively controlled to inhibit the growth of lithium dendrites. (2) The abundant porous structure not only provides huge space for the stable volume expansion/shrinkage of lithium metal, but also allows the electrolyte to penetrate into the composite lithium metal electrode, thus reducing the thickness of the concentration boundary layer to inhibit the growth of lithium dendrites. (3) The hierarchical connecting structure is conducive to the transportation of lithium ions, thereby reducing the interface impedance and increasing the rate capability. And the well-designed frameworks also enable regulating the deposition sites to obtain a dendrite-free surface morphology by controlling the distribution of ions and electrons. In a word, the design of structured three-dimensional framework is the central segment of lithium metal anode materials and deserves extensive attention for practical LMBs. The most researched three-dimensional frameworks can be generally classified as the following categories according to the physical and chemical properties of the materials: carbonaceous frameworks, metallic frameworks, alloyed frameworks, polymer frameworks, MOFs-based frameworks, and MXene-based frameworks. The carbonaceous frameworks with high electronic conductivity promote the uniform deposition of lithium ions on the framework instead of on the concentrated nucleation sites, thereby inhibiting the appearance of lithium dendrites [319]. The higher specific surface area greatly reduces the local current density, resulting in prolonged Sand’s time [270], which also suppresses the lithium dendrites growth. Meanwhile, the hierarchical porous structure can effectively alleviate the volume change of lithium metal. Moreover, the characteristics of light weight, diverse structure, low cost, mature production technology, abundant raw materials have also made carbonaceous frameworks a research hotspot for lithium metal anode. The carbonaceous frameworks mainly include graphene [320], carbon nanotubes [321], carbon fibers [322], and carbonized biomaterials [323]. Chen et al. [324] injected molten Li into carbon fibers coated by porous nano gold film to form a AuLi3 film with extra lithium metal, then the core pre-stripping process took place to remove fractional lithium metal for exposing partial carbon fibers and providing more reserved space. The final three-dimensional frameworks named PS-Li-AuLi3@CF delivered rapid electrode kinetics and an extremely low overpotential due to the lithiophilic AuLi3 phase. And after many cycles, the PS-Li-AuLi3@CF anode could still maintain the original morphology without being buried inside lithium metal, which greatly decreased the internal stresses and provided sufficient space for accommodating the volume fluctuations (Fig. 11 a). The full cell performance indicates a coulombic efficiencies of 99.2% with a capacity retention >96% at 5 C after 1000 cycles matching LiFePO4 and a coulombic efficiencies of 99.8% with a capacity retention >70% at 2 C after 1000 cycles matching sulfur/polyacrylonitrile. The N-doped three-dimensional nanoporous graphene frameworks were introduced into the free-standing composite lithium metal anode, exhibiting ultrahigh electronic conductivity and mechanical stability [325]. The high porosity with nanopores gives rise to large specific surface area and high mass loading of lithium metal about 95.3%. The functional groups generated by a small amount of nitrogen doping greatly improve the lithiophilicity of graphene, which is conducive to the rapid infusion of molten Li for obtaining a uniform layer coated on the three-dimensional nanoporous graphene and achieving a dendrite-free morphology. The outstanding anode showed an excellent full cell performance matching LiFePO4 and a stable rate capability of 12 mAh cm−2 even at a high current density of 24 mA cm−2. The metallic frameworks refer to varied three-dimensional metallic current collectors consisting of Cu current collectors [326], stainless steel current collectors [327], Ni foam [328], Ag nanowires [329]. In comparison with metallic foil, the three-dimensional metallic current collectors show lower effective current density arising from high specific surface area, providing huge lithium storage room for accommodating lithium metal fluctuations and a mechanically stable conductive network. Moreover, the well-designed metallic frameworks coated with lithiophilic materials enable promoting the uniform distribution of Li+ flux and controlling the direction of lithium deposition to obtain a dendrite-free Li plating. Recently, a HCF/CF current collector was fabricated by a simple chemical method of vertically growing hierarchical copper fibers on a copper foam [330]. The copper current collector not only affords large active surface and robust structure for rapid Li plating/stripping, but also provides a considerable number of nanosized raised electrochemically sites on the hierarchical copper fibers to guide the nucleation and growth of lithium metal for a smooth surface (Fig. 11b). The Li metal anode can operate for 820 h at the current density of 1 mA cm−2 in the Li-Li symmetrical cell test, and exhibit a capacity retention of 95% at 2 C after 500 cycles when matching a LiFePO4 cathode in the full cell test. In contrast to numerous freestanding lithium metal anode with carbonaceous frameworks, the mass of the lithium metal anode with three-dimensional copper frameworks is heavier, and copper is an inactive substance in the lithium metal anode, which will both render a decrease in the overall energy density of LMBs. It is also worth mentioning that due to the porosity of the three-dimensional copper framework, the electrolyte will be in direct contact with the collector, which could give rise to some compatibility issues between the electrolyte component and the collector, for example, polysulfide which is customarily used as an electrolyte additive in Li-S batteries can gravely react with copper. For the sake of solving the above issues, Zhang et al. [331] applied treated commercially porous Ti foam to meliorate the compatibility between the electrolyte and collector. What’s more, increased energy density is achieved owing to the relatively lower density of Ti than Cu. As a result, the Li@Ti foam|LiFePO4 full cell with high lithium capacity of 10 mAh cm−2 achieved an excellent electrochemical performance after 1000 cycles in the electrolyte with polysulfide. The novel lithium alloy composite lithium metal anodes are constructed by the reaction between molten Li and targeted elementary substances (such as Si and B) [332,333] or targeted compounds (such as SiO and Al2O3) [334,335] to obtain a porous alloyed frameworks with extra free Li metal. The one-step method simplifies the manufacturing process due to the skip of extra lithium infusion or electrodeposition process. In addition, the alloyed frameworks have the benefits of super lithiophilicity, excellent Li+/electronic conductivity, well-distributed porous structure and good mechanical stability, which deliver predominant electrochemical performance and glossy dendrite-free Li deposition. Recently, another significant function of lithium alloy composite anode has been explored by Li-Sr alloy [336]. The Li-Sr alloy with 11 wt% Sr can form SrF2-rich SEI in a fluorine-containing electrolyte, while SrF2 exhibits high interface energy at Li/SEI and high young’s modulus that even surpasses LiF, which facilitates the lateral deposition of Li metal and suppresses the lithium dendrites formation. The Li-Sr alloy anode achieved a stable cyclic performance at a high current density up to 30 mA cm−2 with an areal capacity of 1 mAh cm−2 in symmetric cells and can still reach a capacity retention of 84.3% at 2 C after 200 cycles in the full cell assembled with LiFePO4. Due to the conductivity of the aforementioned three frameworks, lithium ions can be directly deposited on the conductive frameworks, which conceivably renders the majority of Li deposition occurring on the top of the frameworks instead of filling the inside, thus leading to the failure of the structured framework during the long cycling process. Polymer framework is a non-conductive framework, and lithium ions can only be deposited on the lithium metal inside the framework to form a bottom-up lithium deposition pattern, which subtly solves the issues [337,338]. Meanwhile, with the aid of surface polar functional groups, the polymer framework can regulate the Li+ concentration distribution near the electrode surface by absorbing lithium ions in the electrolyte in advance and releasing lithium ions in the plating process so as to inhibit lithium dendrites formation [257]. In addition, the features of low mass, low cost, high mechanical and chemical stability in the plating process are also the advantages of the polymer used as framework for lithium metal anode. A typical polymer framework composite lithium metal anode was demonstrated by the method of infusing molten Li into ZnO coated interlaced PI fibres (Fig. 11c) [339]. The good heat resistance and chemical inertness can maintain the structural integrity of the framework during the preparation and plating process. The lithiophilic ZnO coating ensures that the molten lithium completely covers the surface of the framework.
