The large porosity relieves the volume change of the lithium metal and reduces the effective current density to obtain a flat voltage curve and low overpotential. By the virtue of polymers, Jiang et al. [340] initially combined PDA and three-dimensional copper current collectors to obtain a hybrid framework for lithium metal anode through a two-step method of controlling the laser to produce a pinhole array and a simple chemical polymerization. The large active surface area of 3D holey Cu reduces the effective current density and inhibits the Li dendrite growth. The realized homogeneous nucleation sites and robust mechanical strength are derived from the super lithiophilic PDA layer. As a result, the PDA@3D Cu electrode can operate steadily for 1000 h with ultralow voltage hysteresis at 0.5 mAh cm−2 and the full cell assembled with LiFePO4 delivers a high capacity retention of 72% after 200 cycles at 0.5 C. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are a multifunctional organic–inorganic hybrid material with intramolecular pores formed by self-assembly of organic ligands and metal ions or clusters [341]. In recent years, its application in solving the interface issues of LMBs has received extensive attention [342,343]. MOFs material has structured and adjustable pore structure with large porosity and huge specific surface area (>1000 m2 g−1), which provides fast Li+ diffusion channels and enhances the rate performance of LMBs. The lithiophilic open metal sites and abundant functional groups in the MOFs homogenize lithium ions flux and decrease the nucleation overpotential to induce a dendrite-free deposition. The MOFs-based frameworks can be achieved through modifying the carbonaceous/metallic frameworks with MOFs materials [344,345], carbonizing MOFs materials [346] and directly employing the MOFs materials modified with lithiophilic sites [347]. Lyu et al. [348] calcined the 3D-printing of Zn-based MOFs stemming from extrusion-based 3D-printing technology at N2 atmosphere to fabricate a 3D-printing N-doped carbon (3D-NC) framework. The 3D-printing of Zn-based MOFs consists of many pores (~300 μm) due to the mesh-like structure with interconnected filaments. After carbonization and evaporation of zinc, the structure remains stable, but numerous micro-pores and meso-pores emerge, which contributes to the increased areal capacity and a high specific surface area of 894 m2 g−1. The N-doped carbon provides the lithiophilic seeds for the uniform Li nucleation and retards the Li dendrite formation. Such a composite lithium metal anode delivered a high areal capacity of 30 mAh cm−2 at the current density of 10 mA cm−2 and the full cell matching 3D-printed LiFePO4 cathode exhibited a high specific capacity at 10 C and retained the original capacity when returning to 0.5 C. MXene is a state-of-the-art graphene-like material with superior electronic conductivity and rapid ion transportation, which sheds a huge spotlight on rechargeable lithium storage [349,350]. The rich lithiophilic surface functional groups on the MXene nanosheets enable stabilizing the Li/electrolyte interface and guiding the uniform lithium deposition. And the MXene film has the features of light weight and ultrathin thinkness (<30 μm), which give rise to the high Li utilization and high energy density of composite lithium metal anodes. Futhermore, the mechanical and flexible properties of MXene-based frameworks have also been recently explored for the advanced flexible LMBs. Wang et al. [351] employed the spin evaporation technology to construct a flexible and self-supporting Ti3C2T x MXene/cellulose nanofiber composite framework. The MXene microspheres with composite cellulose nanofiber are formed between the MXene sheets through intermolecular hydrogen bonding. Such robust interlocked microstructure greatly enhances the mechanical flexibility of the MXene films and avoids the restacking of MXene sheets to create large space for high areal capacity and increased Li+ kinetics (Fig. 11d). The obtained composite lithium metal anode can operate steadily for 1300 h with low voltage polarization of 47 mV at the current density of 0.5 mA cm−2. And the MXene@CNF/Li||LFP full cell exibits a much higher specific capacity than Cu/Li||LFP cell at high current density and a high capacity retention of 94 % after 200 cycles. In brief, the design of new structured anode materials, especially various three-dimensional frameworks, is a powerful strategy to accommodate the volumetric change of lithium metal and guide the behavior of dendrites-free lithium deposition for excellent electrochemical performance and security. However, the development of the current frameworks is still limited for lithium metal anodes with high energy density, prominent cyclic stability and mature technology. Several factors, such as heavy inactive materials in the composite lithium metal anode, thick lithium metal electrodes and high negative/positive electrode areal capacity ratio (N/P ratio) have severely decreased the energy density of LMBs. Considerable efforts should be made to further reduce the weight ratio and volume ratio of the inactive materials, explore advanced technology or materials to produce lithium electrodes less than 30 μm [352], and fabricate free-standing electrodes with high electronic conductivity. Although the high specific surface area of three-dimensional frameworks can reduce the effective current density of the electrodes, the consumption of extra active lithium and electrolyte renders a relatively low initial coulombic efficiency. In addition, some frameworks have poor mechanical strength and compatibility issues between frameworks and electrolyte, which will give rise to the failure of original structure during prolonged cycles. With the purpose of solving these problems, more microstructured composite frameworks with improved interface chemistry should be explored for instance the novel gradient frameworks [353]. The lithiophilicity and conductivity of the internal framework enable promoting the uniform lithium nucleation and guide the deposition behavior of lithium metal, while the external protective layer has high ionic conductivity and mechanical strength, which can not only isolate the SEI from the protective layer, but also maintain the structural integrity of the composite anode. The two most employed manufacturing methods of composite lithium metal anodes in the laboratories are the electrodeposition method and the melting-diffusion method, which are not suitable for large-scale production due to the tedious process and high reactivity of molten lithium in the atmosphere, hence seeking a simple and controllable method is also an urgent task for practical application of composite lithium metal anodes. Furthermore, theoretical researches on the electrochemical mechanism of lithium deposition in the three-dimensional frameworks should also be advanced simultaneously to pave the way for advanced structured lithium metal anodes. 2.5.6 Anode-free lithium metal batteries The lithium foils or lithium metal anodes used in the aforementioned strategies generally have a thickness of more than 100 μm with much excess lithium inventory to compensate the loss of active lithium arising from the formation of dead lithium and SEI during the cycling process [354]. Although the lithium reservoir can effectively improve the coulombic efficiency and cycle stability of lithium metal anodes, the excess weight greatly reduces the energy density of lithium metal anodes and some thick lithium foils even deliver a specific capacity less than graphite anode, which contradicts the original intention of researching lithium metal anodes [355]. Nowadays, some methods or synergetic strategies can effectively increase the coulombic efficiency of lithium metal anodes up to 99.8%, so reducing the amount of excess lithium inventory or the thickness of lithium foil has become an inevitable requirement [356]. However, it is still challenging to manufacture lithium foils less than 50 μm with the current technology [357]. Hence, an ingenious idea: anode-free lithium metal batteries (AFLMBs), was initially proposed in 2000 [358] and re-emphasized the promising practical value by Qian in 2016 [359]. The exclusive configuration difference between AFLMBs and LMBs is that the anode of AFLMBs only contains Cu current collector without lithium metal (Fig. 12 a and b). During the cycling process, all active lithium derives from the lithium-rich cathode like LiFePO4, which means that lithium ions are directly plated on the Cu current collector during the charge process and the deposited metallic lithium is the only available lithium source during the discharge process. AFLMBs possess the following advantages. (1) Owing to the absence of lithium metal, the overall weight and volume of the battery are greatly reduced and the energy density can be significantly improved. (2) The corrosion and malignant side reactions of lithium metal are greatly avoided or inhibited in both storage and working condition, thereby improving security. (3) The complicated manufacturing and assembly process of the lithium foil are omitted, which simplifies the manufacturing process and reduces the cost. In the ideal scenario of AFLMBs, lithium ions extracted from the cathode are deposited on the Cu current collector and all return to the cathode during the discharge process with 100% coulombic efficiency, so we believe that AFLMBs are the ultimate version of LMBs assembled with lithium metal and intercalation type cathode. However, due to no excess lithium for the compensation of capacity loss during cycling, AFLMBs present much lower coulombic efficiency and worse cycling stability compared to LMBs. Therefore, AFLMBs can not only be employed as a promising and independent battery system, but also bring about greater challenges for the optimization strategy of LMBs and provide a convenient full cell test platform to reveal the true coulombic efficiency [360]. Recently, Huang et al. [361] decoupled the origins of irreversible coulombic efficiency in AFLMBs and proposed integrated protocols for the insightful guidance of future design. When AFLMBs use layered oxide cathodes with first intrinsic irreversible capacity, the lithium ions that cannot be reinserted into the cathode become the excess lithium remaining on the Cu current collector in the form of lithium metal. In the subsequent several cycles, the irreversible coulombic efficiency mostly originates from the cathode. Meanwhile, the excess lithium on the anode is constantly being consumed to compensate for other irreversible capacity losses. When the active lithium inventory is exhausted, the capacity shows a sudden decline and another stage is coming up, in which stage the irreversible coulombic efficiency of AFLMBs mostly derives from the dead lithium generated in each cycle, subsequent SEI formation, and cross-talk effect. When the first intrinsic irreversible capacity of the layered oxide cathodes could be ignored, then the first irreversible coulombic efficiency stems from the total of first SEI formation, dead Li, subsequent SEI and cross-talk effect. Therefore, it is crucial for AFLMBs to choose a suitable cathode material, suppress the formation of dead lithium and form an ultrathin and stable SEI. In recent years, booming progresses have been made to improve the coulombic efficiency of AFLMBs and provide conceivable directions for advanced LMBs and AFLMBs, including modified Cu current collectors, well-designed protocols and optimized electrolytes (Fig. 13 ). The biggest difference between AFLMBs and LMBs during the first charge is that the lithium ions from the cathode are directly plated on the Cu current collector instead of on the lithium metal. However, large nucleation overpotential and uneven Li+/electron distribution are generated on the planar Cu current collector, which easily render dendritic or mossy lithium deposition, thereby producing dead lithium and causing capacity loss [355]. In order to solve the above issues, employing lithium alloy current collectors [363], designing three-dimensional porous current collectors [364] and constructing artificial lithiophilic coatings [365] are all effective strategies. Well-designed protocols can significantly improve the cycling performance without altering the battery configuration. Louli et al. [354,366] successively indicated that increasing the externally constrained pressure to the appropriate range, setting the charge speed 2.5 times slower than the discharge speed and limiting the depth of discharge can effectively increase the lifetime. Genovese et al. [367] proposed a “hot formation” strategy which means that the batteries experience two high temperature (40 °C) cycles first and the following low temperature (20 °C) cycles could significantly improve the average coulombic efficiency of AFLMBs. Based on these theories, more complex intermittent protocols and synergetic strategies can be proposed to achieve a satisfactory performance. However, due to appended charge/discharge restrictions and harsh external conditions, some protocols are actually not suitable for practical applications. In contrast, the electrolyte is the foremost component of AFLMBs, because it directly affects the voltage window, the quality of SEI, the nucleation and growth of lithium metal, and the coulombic efficiency. Up to now, the best cycling performances of AFLMBs [362,367,368] have been achieved through different concentrations or compositions of lithium salts and solvents under different external protocols. Yu et al. [362] reasonably synthesized a new solvent FDMB with a unique Li-F interaction, which is capable of dissolving more Li+ and enhancing the Li metal compatibility (Fig. 12c). The anode-free Cu|NMC811 (LiNi0.8Mn0.1Co0.1O2) pouch cells paired with 1 M LiFSI/FDMB electrolyte delivered an extremely high capacity retention of 80% after 100 cycles and ~325 Wh kg−1 single-cell energy density. Compared with other advanced AFLMBs with some favourable conditions, this AFLMBs was tested under rigorous or practical conditions, such as 100% depth of discharge, lean electrolyte, none electrolyte additives, uncontrolled room temperature and low pressure. In addition, densely packed lithium deposition and uniform SEI with ultrathin thickness of 6 nm were observed, which further demonstrated the excellent performance of the electrolyte system. More researches on the optimization of collocations, concentration and molecular structure for the electrolyte should be emphasized to further improve the comprehensive electrochemical performance of AFLMBs. As AFLMBs is still in its infancy, numerous mechanism researches and computational simulations are urgently needed to explore the influence of electrolyte and current collector on the lithium plating/stripping process. Meanwhile, advanced current collectors should facilitate homogeneous deposition morphology. And researches on high-energy cathodes should also be carried out simultaneously to ensure Li+ insertion/deintercalation with high efficiency and negligible inherent capacity loss. 3 Conclusions and perspectives Rechargeable lithium batteries have undergone 30 years of brilliant development since their initial commercialization, which are accompanied by the evolution of the anode materials especially during the past two decades. In this review, we briefly summarize the challenges and corresponding solutions of the four representative anode materials: graphite, Li4Ti5O12, silicon and lithium metal. The story on the development history of anode materials is long but fascinating, and the road ahead must be tortuous but pregnant. To help readers better understand the core vision of the review, we draw a timeline of the development history for the four representative anode materials containing their emergence time and selected important breakthroughs. Next, we will respectively make conclusive comments and prospects for the four anode materials. For decades to come, graphite will still be the mainstream anode materials for commercial LIBs, and deeper researches on the graphite/electrolyte interface and rate capability are still indispensable to promote the development of LIBs. With the rapid development of various advanced characterization techniques and theoretical computational tools in recent years, more precise information and underlying mechanisms regarding the formation and components of SEI, co-intercalation phenomenon, and Li+ diffusion from electrolyte to graphite bulk will be attainable to provide novel insights and principles for the design of graphite materials, electrolytes and cell structure. For the graphite/electrolyte interface, exploiting new electrolyte systems with moderate electrolyte additives or employing high-quality coatings are of great importance to build a desirable SEI with powerful properties and compatibility. The fast-charging capability determines the competitiveness of graphite anodes and the popularity of electric vehicles in the future, so researches should further accelerate the Li+ diffusion rates in the four stages (electrolyte, desolvation, SEI and graphite bulk) based on new fundamental insights, especially when crossing the interface. Meanwhile, the safety of commercial LIBs is a top priority. For graphite anodes, uncontrollable lithium metal deposition and growth can easily occur on the graphite surface under the scenarios of fast-charging and low-temperature. Except for enhancing the Li+ transport dynamics, the design of non-flammable solvents or advanced solid-state electrolytes with excellent low-temperature performance could be feasible solutions and research directions. Besides, another significant tendency for commercial graphite anodes is to combine with a small amount of silicon oxide/elemental silicon to improve the specific capacity without sacrificing cycle stability and ICE, so the further design of ingenious graphite/Si or graphite/SiO x composite structures with low cost is valuable to meet the needs of relatively high energy density during the transition period of anode materials for rechargeable lithium batteries. In short, when we attempt to combine various advanced technologies for a commercial anode, the feasibility of cost-efficient mass production and environmental benignancy should also be taken into consideration. Spinel Li4Ti5O12 will continue to play an unique and requisite role in the commercial anode materials for LIBs due to its great safety and superior cycle stability arising from the negligible volume changes during cycling, which has been reported to enable cycling for 25000 times and powering the EV for over 50000 km in more than one year. However, two major obstacles of intrinsically low conductivity and energy density restrict the further development of Li4Ti5O12 anode. In this review, we briefly introduce the effective strategies of designing nano/microstructures and structural modifications to improve the rate capability of Li4Ti5O12 anodes, in which designing hierarchical microstructures with high-quality carbon coatings could be the most promising strategy to improve the overall electrochemical performance. Besides, if an inexpensive elemental dopant can be easily added into the Li4Ti5O12 preparation process without side effect, the intrinsic conductivity of Li4Ti5O12 could be greatly enhanced. From the perspective of industrial production, the cost of Li4Ti5O12 is still much higher than that of graphite, not to mention carbon coating or ion doping. Therefore, more researches can focus on the development of cost-efficient solid-state preparation methods and applying inexpensive inorganic precursors into the liquid-state method while introducing the carbon source in-situ during the preparation process. On the other hand, the low energy density encourages the emergence of various self-supporting flexible Li4Ti5O12 anodes without binders and conductive agents to increase the energy density due to the reduction of inactive materials. Furthermore, researches on assembling a full battery with Li4Ti5O12 anode and different cathodes could be a direct pathway to optimize the performance of Li4Ti5O12-based batteries. For example, employ a high-voltage cathode and a stable electrolyte system to increase the energy density, and seek the suitable cathodes with similar structure and properties to enhance the inherent advantages of Li4Ti5O12 anode for a full battery with high power density and ultralong cycles, which all deserves further tests and evaluation under different conditions. Silicon has been recognized as the most promising anode material for the next-generation high-energy LIBs due to the ultrahigh theoretical capacity, low lithiation potential and abundant reserves. However, graphite will not be totally replaced by silicon in the near-term future due to the unsolved industrial technical problems. Actually some electric vehicle companies have already doped a handful of silicon and supplementary lithium into graphite anodes and announced that they will develop all-silicon batteries for higher energy density and lower cost. Therefore, the content of silicon in the anode will continue to increase over time. In this review, we systematically summarized the advantages, preparation methods, disadvantages and corresponding solutions of silicon anodes in different dimensions from 0D nanoparticles to 3D porous silicon and introduced the design and preparation of various sophisticated silicon composite anode structures with greatly enhanced electrochemical performance such as the ICE, cycle stability, energy density and rate capability, which will accumulate precious experience for future advanced silicon anodes. The greatest challenges of silicon anodes are the huge volume expansion and low conductivity. Designing silicon nanostructure could be an effective strategy, but it suffers from low tap density and low ICE which requires additional assembly processes and lithium supplement measures, and the manufacturing cost of nano-silicon is still high due to the lack of a facile and reproducible method, which all limits the practical application of nano-silicon anodes. Hence, exploiting a cheap silicon source to produce micron-sized porous silicon with controlled porosity could be a feasible pathway to realize the commercial application of silicon materials. Besides, compounding with carbon materials has been extensively pursued as the most promising strategy currently, but the carbon source, the ratio of silicon to carbon and the compatibility with industrial production lines should be carefully considered. In addition, the choice of binder with strong mechanical properties is also vital for silicon anodes, and more functional conductive binders can be researched and synthesized to accelerate the commercialization process of silicon anodes [369]. Finally, further researches should focus on combining various isolated structures and strategies to form a complete system for the synergistic effects, which presumably open up a new stage in silicon anode research. Simultaneously, more detailed lithiation/delithiation mechanism of silicon anodes with different morphologies and the processes of charge transfer at electrode/electrolyte or electrode/coating interface should also be investigated by advanced in-situ techniques to reveal the origin of high-performance silicon-based anodes and provide a guiding role to optimize the design of silicon-based LIBs. It is worth noting that most researches on the anodes of LIBs merely perform a half-cell test with lithium metal foil as the counter-electrode which contains exhaustless lithium content and little potential variation during charge and discharge. Although the half-cell test is convenient to verify the intrinsic and basic electrochemical performance of a new strategy, the depletion of limited active lithium is the main reason for the performance degradation in practical full battery, which is also associated with the selection of cathode material and the negative/positive capacity ratio [133]. Therefore, the half-cell test is not reliable to truly reveal the coulombic efficiency and average lithiation/delithiation voltage, and the data of full-cell test is imperative to optimize the design strategy and verify its practicability. Lithium metal anode has been considered as be the ultimate goal and optimal choice for rechargeable lithium batteries, which is capable of significantly changing the situation in energy storage field and promoting the development of battery technology due to the ultrahigh energy densities of different LMBs. Nevertheless, serious safety issues and rapid capacity decay arising from the uncontrollable lithium dendrite growth and unstable SEI are still huge challenges for practical applications. In this review, we have generally presented the growth process of lithium dendrites, summarized four effective strategies to inhibit the lithium dendrites formation and the lithium metal fluctuation, and finally introduced the recent advances on anode-free LMBs. In recent years, the focus of lithium battery research is gradually shifting from LIBs to LMBs and numerous striking achievements have been obtained. For example, Zhou’s team [4,370,371] synthesized a low-cost Li2O@Ni-CAC cathode with the specific capacity for the entire cathode up to 477 mAh g−1 and assembled with a modified ether-based electrolyte and limited Li-metal anode to successfully fabricate a practical 500 Wh kg−1 lithium metal pouch cell, which provides novel ideas for building a new type of high-energy LMBs system. Except for the strategies and factors mentioned in this view, the choice of electrolyte and the applied external pressure also have great influence on LMBs. Niu et al. [254] prepared Li||NMC622 pouch cell with the baseline energy density of 300 Wh kg−1 and concluded that the degradation of lithium metal anode was the main reason for the rapid battery failure in such condition. When successively applying a compatible electrolyte and external pressure of 10 psi, a thin and dense SEI was produced and the electrolyte could fully infiltrate the well contacted lithium particles, resulting in the much reduced cell swelling and a capacity retention of 86% after 200 cycles. Similar to the relationship between the half-cell test and the full-cell test, the electrochemical performance varies greatly between coin-cell and pouch-cell configurations for LMBs. For coin-cell configuration, the cycle life of lithium metal anodes can be simply improved by manipulating the electrolyte amount, Li anode thickness and cathode loading, and there is no unified standard to limit the range of experimental conditions, so a rigorous and practical pouch cell with minimum parasitic weight (such as binder, conductive additives) and a limited negative/positive capacity ratio (N/P ratio) and electrolyte weight/cell capacity ratio (E/C ratio) to enhance the energy density (based on the overall quality of pouch cell) should be greatly recommended to evaluate the actual performance of LMBs [372]. Although the large N/P ratio could provide sufficient lithium inventory, a limited N/P ratio (<3) with a thin Li metal foil (<50 μm) contributes ro reduced weight and cost of pouch cell, so the manufacturing issues of ultrathin lithium foil or lithium metal anode should be further researched to increase the energy density if the LMBs can still maintain a sufficiently high coulombic efficiency. Furthermore, it is far from enough to concentrate on one strategy to improve the performance of lithium metal anodes. In the future, more researches should focus on how to combine two or more strategies ingeniously to further improve the coulombic efficiency and energy density of lithium metal anodes. For instance, Shen et al. [373] prepared a housed Li metal anode with the CFs framework and in-situ formed solid electrolyte protection layer, which can not only prevent lithium metal from contacting the electrolyte, but also greatly accelerate and homogenize the lithium ion flux. Lee et al. [374] integrated sulfide solid electrolytes and Ag-C anode framework into an anode-free configuration to obtain an all-solid-state LMBs with a high energy density of >900 Wh L−1 and stable cycles for over 1000 cycles. In brief, rechargeable lithium batteries will experience the golden age of lithium metal anodes, and tremendously more efforts can be made on the fundamental mechanism, anode structure design, electrolyte design and battery engineering before the commercialization of LMBs. Nowadays, except for focusing on improving the intrinsic defects of anode materials, the possible variation of market demand and application scenarios for rechargeable lithium batteries should also be continuously paid attention to. For instance, the extreme working environments require electrode materials with excellent high/low temperature performance, and emerging intelligent flexible electronic devices require self-supporting flexible electrode materials [375]. Furthermore, since lithium is a relatively rare and expensive metal, the recycling and sustainable development of energy storage materials have been considered as the new issues. Na-ion batteries have been pursued as the most promising technology to compete with Li-ion batteries in the future commercial battery market due to the much abundant element reserves and excellent electrochemical performance [376]. And the mature theories of lithium batteries can also provide significative guidance for sodium batteries arising from many similarities between Li-ion chemistry and Na-ion chemistry, so the rapid development of rechargeable sodium batteries is expected. Besides, various metal-air batteries with aqueous-based electrolytes are becoming an unstoppable tendency to replace lithium battery in the future due to sustainability and low cost, but currently they still face many complicated issues both from metal anodes and air cathode. With the booming development of material science and in-situ analytical techniques, we believe that more advanced material synthesis technology and novel energy storage concepts will provide electrochemist with profound insight and huge opportunities to promote the sustainable development of energy chemistry. (2021) Liqiang Zhang obtained his Bachelor and Master degree from Guilin University of Electronic Technology in 2009. He received his Ph.D. degree in mechatronic engineering from Jiangsu University in 2013 and later worked as a postdoctoral fellow at College of Engineering and Applied Sciences at Nanjing University. He currently is an associate professor of School of Mechanical Engineering at Jiangsu University. His research interests focus on packaging reliability and heat management of batteries. Chenxi Zhu obtained his Bachelor in mechatronic engineering from Jiangsu University in 2020. Now, he is a Master candidate of School of Mechanical Engineering at Jiangsu University. His research interests focus on anode materials and reliability for Li-ion batteries. Sicheng Yu obtained his Bachelor in mechatronic engineering from Suqian College in 2019. Now, he is a Master candidate of School of Mechanical Engineering at Jiangsu University. His research interests focus on anode materials and reliability for Li-ion batteries. Daohan Ge received her Bachelor degree in physic from Nanjing University in 2005 and obtained her Ph.D. degree in microelectronics and solid state electronics from Shanghai Institute of Microsystem and Information Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences in 2010. She currently is associate professor and Ph.D. supervisor of School of Mechanical Engineering at Jiangsu University. During the period from 2017 to 2018, she was a visiting scholar in University of New South Wales. Her research interests focus on MEMS, nano materials, photonic devices, and biosensor. Haoshen Zhou obtained his Bachelor in Nanjing University in 1985 and received his Ph.D. from the University of Tokyo in 1994. He is the prime senior researcher of National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology and the professor in Nanjing University. His research interests include the synthesis of functional materials and their applications in Li-ion batteries, Na-ion batteries, Li-redox flow batteries, metal-air batteries, and new type batteries and cells.

coredata.dc:description: Rechargeable lithium batteries have been widely regarded as a revolutionary technology to store renewable energy sources and extensively researched in the recent several decades. As an indispensable part of lithium batteries, the evolution of anode materials has significantly promoted the development of lithium batteries. However, since conventional lithium batteries with graphite anodes cannot meet the ever-increasing demands in different application scenarios (such as electric vehicles and large-scale power supplies) which require high energy/power density and long cycle life, various improvement strategies and alternative anode materials have been exploited for better electrochemical performance. In this review, we detailedly introduced the characteristics and challenges of four representative anode materials for rechargeable lithium batteries, including graphite, Li4Ti5O12, silicon, and lithium metal. And some of the latest advances are summarized, which mainly contain the modification strategies of anode materials and partially involve the optimization of electrode/electrolyte interface. Finally, we make the conclusive comments and perspectives, and draw a development timeline on the four anode materials. This review aims to offer a good primer for newcomers in the lithium battery field and benefit the structure and material design of anodes for advanced rechargeable lithium batteries in the future.
